titleStmt.title: Old Tibetan Manuscripts from East Turkestan in the Stein Collection of the British Library
titleStmt.author: Takeuchi, Tsuguhito

editionStmt.respStmt: Imported into XML by Sam van Schaik 11/11/05. Edited by Márta Matkó.

publicationStmt.publisher: The Toyo Bunko and The British Library

encodingDesc.editorialDecl: Imported to 4D on xx/xx/xx by Sam van Schaik.

text.head: This is a catalogue of the Tibetan manuscripts in the Stein collection. In particular, it covers the paper manuscripts from Central Asian sites other than Dunhuang. Most of these manuscripts come from the Khotan and Lop-nor regions, and were gathered during all three of Stein's major Central Asian expeditions.

note.p: Middle portion of a document. R1 has a phrasemyI mchI bar"not to go (or say)"; r2 containsrgya-log"Chinese rebellions(?)." There is a space between r3 and r4. Too fragmentary for further identification.

Middle portion of probably personal correspondence. The form of address is missing due to paper damage.shog-shog(?) "paper" (r1) may be a present sent with the letter. R2 containsbzhes-par ci gnang"please accept [this present]."

Upper middle portion. R1 gives the date "new-moon day of the twenty-seventh day of the middle [month]," a phrase commonly found in loan contracts.mye-skad(r2) may readmye-skrad"extinguish fire."Shing-shan"Tibetan name forMazār Tāgh" seems to be mentioned in r3.

msItem.type: document, sale contract?; Chinese document on verso

note.p: Upper? middle part of probably a sale contract.Yang ring-tsud(r2) may be one of the two sellers. Eightsha-bzan"castrated adult male sheep" (r3) seem to be the price. The object for sale is unknown due to paper damage. R1 mentions the place name (Shing-) where [the assembly of] thekhrom"military district government" was held in the year when the contract was made. Verso is frag. of a Chinese document ({CH}, an inter-office communiqué) regarding provisions.

Upper middle part of a letter addressed toMang-rtsan. The left and right edges seem to have been cut off. Lines have been drawn along the left, top, and right edges, as well as obliquely through the middle.

A letter fromBtsan-lodtoKhag lha-skyes({CH}). Complete except for the lower left corner being torn off. Three creases indicate that it was once folded. The form of address was written on verso of the folded paper (not included in Plates). Note thatsolis written forgsol(v1). The inverted line on recto is probably the beginning of another letter. Paper shape and writing style resemble Text 52.

note.p: Upper left corner of a letter addressed tojo-co(lord)Btsan-ba(r1). R2–r5 are greetings.

Upper middle portion. Writing on both sides is probably by the same hand. Recto is a letter. The sender's name is party legible asSrIn-snga[--](r1).'U-neng(r2) seems to be a place name. Verso is probably the lower part of another letter.

Left half of a letter tolord(jo-cho)Khri-bzher. R3 mentions "one Chinese bushel (rgya-khal) of barley." In r4–r5 the sender is asking the addressee to receive something. Verso, written apparently by the same hand as recto, may be the form of address, in which the sender's name is stated asMkhar-slebs.

Upper middle portion. Paper is smudged; writing is faint and illegible except for a few unconnected syllables. R3 seems to contain[gro] bre"breof wheat."
Upper middle portion. Only the sender's nameStag-slebsis legible.

note.p: Middle portion of possibly a letter. A personal nameMang-zigsis legible in r1.

Paper is badly damaged and smudged; characters are worn and illegible, except for a few unconnected syllables. R4 containsgla ni"as for wage." Only one line seems to be written on verso, but very faint. A few syllables, such asmchid-gsolandngan, are legible.
Frag. of probably a Buddhist text.smon-lamappears in r7 and probably also in r6;smon-lham(r4) seems to be a variant spelling.[phu]n-sum-tshogscan be made out in r8.

Three small frags. have been placed together; one contains part of possibly two large Chinese characters (not included in Plates). The other two bear Tibetan writing. Both contain only a few characters; apparently from the same text, but their relative position is unknown. The nameRgyal-to-reis legible on the smaller frag.; the larger one has a line reading:] god rnam g[nyis].
Paper is cut in the shape of a flower with five holes. Recto seems to be a contract with a round vermilion seal affixed below the text. Only two syllables are legible on verso.

Nine small frags. previously placed in a sack with a slip recording site numbers Mr-tagh [= M.Tagh.] 0408–0428. No site number appears on each frag. Four pieces (two each) have been joined to form two frags., thus reducing the overall number to seven. Since M.Tagh. 0410–0428. are used to designate other mss. or materials, these frags. are here designated as M.Tagh. 0408 a–f. Each frag. is described under a different text number. Text 30 contains only a few syllables.
Two frags. have been joined.rta"horse" andskur-ba"to send" are legible on the reconstructed text. For the site number and requisition number, see Text 30.

Two frags. have been joined. The reconstructed ms. is a frag. cut in the shape of a crescent. Only one or two characters are legible in each line. For the site number and requisition number, see Text 30.

Writing on both sides by different hands. Both recto and verso are very faint and illegible, except for a few unconnected syllables such as,gyIs(r2),gcIg(r5), and'ong(v2). For the site number and requisition number, see Text 30.
Writing on both sides by different hands. Only a few syllables in r1 are legible. For the site number and requisition number, see Text 30.

note.p: Only a few characters in r2 are legible. For the site number and requisition number, see Text 30.

msItem.q: ] glu mtho[

note.p: Upper right portion. Concerns hiring people(?) for forty days.Li mkar-pa(r1) "town people of Khotan," andShing-shan-kyI mkar-pa(r3) "town people ofMazār Tāgh" appear.mkar(r4) is used formkhar;klas(r2) forglas.spa'(r4) is probably a Khotanese official titlespā.

Lower middle part of a contract. Partly legible finger-measure seal (mdzub-mo-tshad) is ofLi she-nir, who is probably the debtor. There is also a round vermilion seal, on which asvastikaand the nameDruṁ shin-le[-i-]are inscribed.

Two frags. have been joined together. The reunited text is the lower middle portion. A hand-letter-measure (sug-yig-tshad) appears at the end upside down; the ethnic name'A-zhais used to designate the debtor. The blank space is crossed out by oblique lines. The remaining text however does not conform with the contract formula; it may be a petition. The creases indicate that the paper was once folded. Two syllables written independently on verso were probably written on the folded paper.
Upper middle portion. Probably a register of debtors. A line is drawn horizontally above each name, indicating that his loan has been cleared.

Text seems to mention capture of persons in theHan-tshedirection, and a servant (g.yog) of a porter (ltang-gtsogsforltang-sogs?)Rtsan-rtse, who is a visitor ('dron-pho?).Khom-skyes dbo-kol(r2) appears to be a personal name.

note.p: Recto is the lower right portion of a contract.Lha-sbyin(r4) may be the debtor.dpang-rgya"witness seal" appears in r4. An inverted line is part of a hand-letter-measure (sug-yig-tshad). A round vermilion seal is visible, but illegible. Verso text is smudged and only partly legible.Dru-guis mentioned in v3.
Right portion of probably a letter.Men-trisilk seems to be mentioned in r3.Bod-yulappears in r5 and r6. Verso may be part of the form of address.
Lower middle portion of probably a letter.rje(r3) may be part of the addressee's name.

Lower right portion. The phrase "we make witness seals (or a contract)" (r1) andring-lugs"commission" (r2) suggest that the text is of a legal nature, but it does not conform with the contract formula. The blank space below the text indicates that r3 is the end of the text, and the ending phrase of r3 "please grant a favour" suggests that the text may be a petition.

Left portion. Paper badly damaged and smudged; some characters are not legible. R2 mentions two Tibetans and two Khotanese [to be stationed] atMthong-rtse.Tshugs-ponofficial (or commander) mentioned in r4 and r5 may be interpreted as "atshugs-poncommander [of the]Sum-pa [tribe named] G.yar mog-seng." R5 mentions "atshugs-pon[as a commander] of two Khotanese."

note.p: A red discolouration spreads from the centre, but is not likely a seal.Sbur-cung(r1) is probably the sender.men-trisilk is mentioned in r4;ka-chag"abuse" in r5. The blank space below the text indicates that r6 is the end of the letter.

Recto is lower left part of a letter fromGsas-srong. Consisted of two frags. of paper. Since they were glued together incorrectly, r13 and r14 overlapped. Thus, the two frags. were separated during the conservation process. The line on verso is written by the same hand as recto. Another character likemais visible near the top edge, but is not clear.
Lower left portion. The form of address is missing due to paper damage. Only greetings remain on recto. The line on verso may be the concluding part of the letter or an instruction about delivery.

Upper right portion. R1 says "Enemies having appeared at [. . .], soldiers assembled and moved to'U-ten(= Khotan), then reached the enemies' rear." A phrase in r2snga-skyIn-du 'tshal-te"borrowed as advance loan" suggests that the text is a loan contract, but the rest of the text does not conform to the contract formula. Personal names and district names in probably the Khotan area are mentioned in r3.

A letter fromLa stag-bal[d]to a nephewBtshan-raand nieceLha-ldem. The character r in the last syllable of the sender's name is written on the right top of the character l. -s inphyogs(r1) is written at the beginning of r2. Paper and writing style resemble Text 6. Five creases indicate that the paper was once folded, and the line on verso was written accordingly.

note.p: Right portion of possibly a letter. R2 seems to say "last year I acted as a courier." R3 has "[grain or tax?] was insufficient during the first [winter] month; inShing-shan(=Mazār Tāgh)." A line of Tibetan is partly visible on verso, but illegible.

Right half; paper smudged and writing partly illegible. The main text is on recto. Though the form of address is missing due to paper damage, personal names, such asStag-bzang klu-mthongandStab(?) btsan-zigs, appear in r2 and r7.dong-tse"copper coin" is mentioned in r7. The blank space below r7 suggests that originally there were eight lines on recto. The line on verso is probably the form of address;Shing-shan(=Mazār Tāgh) may be the destination.

msItem.type: document, letter type 3; Khotanese on recto

note.p: Tibetan text, written below a line of Khotanese, seems to be the beginning of a letter by a Khotanese high-ranking official, residing probably in Khotan, and addressed to the highest civil official ofShin(=Shing)-shan, who was probably a Tibetan. Text reads "A-ma-cha Yongrequests to thertse-rjeofShin-shan." The expression "thertse-rjeofShin-shan" suggests that there were certain inhabitants inMazār Tāghgoverned by artse-rjeor town prefect. Khotanese writing may be an instruction about delivery (see5:204and199).

msItem.type: document, letter?; Buddhist Tantric text, dhāraṇi or mantra?

note.p: A long slip of paper with its left edge torn off. Recto is probably a letter, but both the form of address and the concluding part are missing. Verso, written apparently by a different hand from recto, seems to be the beginning of a mantra.

Lower left portion of probably a letter. Its upper part has been cut off and the right edge torn off. Writing on both sides is apparently by the same hand; verso is a continuation from recto. Both the names of sender and addressee are missing.drug(r3) may be a variant forDru-gu"Türk," used as a place name here.

The beginning of the line on verso, written apparently by the same hand as recto, may be the form of address. If so, the letter is addressed to themnganofficial inShing-shan.

R2 says that'og-ponis responsible for extinguishing fires and preparing meals at day-encampment. R4 seems to speak of "if horse(s) flee . . . ." V1 suggests the text may be a petition.

Addressed tojo-boRgyal-bzang.The sender's name is mostly missing due to paper damage. Since the left edge is torn off, a few characters are missing at the beginning of each line. Another letter toRgyal-bzang, by the same hand, starts in the middle of r7 and ends in r10. Though the bottom edge is torn off, r10 is most probably the last line of the letter. Verso is probably a letter draft written by the same hand as recto, but too faint to read except for the syllable'drul. Two lines of small holes appear near the right, bottom, and left edges (cf. Text 90).

Left portion. Paper smudged and writing indistinct. Only a few phrases, such asthugs-rje cir gnang"please grant [your] compassion" andsla tha-cungs"the last month," can be made out on recto. Another document apparently by another hand is on verso.

note.p: Two pieces of the same letter, but cannot be joined together. The larger piece is the upper right portion. Names of the sender and addressee are missing due to paper damage. The syllable'buland characterlaon verso may be part of the form of address, written after the paper was folded. Only the syllablegda'is legible on the smaller piece.

msItem.type: document, sale contract; military, list of stationing or placement of soldiers?

note.p: Recto is the left half of a sale contract. The objects for sale are a saber and something else unidentified. The seller's name isLi mar-pon, a Khotanese belonging to the parish ofZhum-ba. The buyer, whose name is missing due to paper damage, belongs to theYang-rtsangregiment.gives the wrong site number M.Tagh. 0500. Verso is the right half of a military document. Many personal names and place names in the Khotan area are listed. Cf. Texts 247 and 309.

Right half of a letter fromLegs-tshan. The form of address on verso indicates that it is addressed to LordStag rgyal-bzher; he is referred to asjo-bo lha-dpalin r1. R3 says "[I am] sending five large and smallleb'slatesorribbons' toTshes-lod," probably the wife ofStag rgyal-bzher(381). In r4 the sender wishes to set eyes upon the auspicious face of the addressee.
Lower(?) middle part. The sender's name is partly legible as-gsas; the addressee's name is missing. Verso is probably the form of address.

Two pieces of the same ms., a contract for borrowingdmar(?). Text reconstructed from the reunited frags., which still lacks the upper edge, is given here. The paper is coloured red. The debtor's name isRme'u byin-la-gsas.

] /:/ lugI lo'i dbya[r] [
] [- - glo? --] [b]th[

note.p: A petition letter by'Phan (la)-ryaandNya-brtsanto'Phan-gzigs. An official square seal in vermilion ink is partly visible near the left edge. The first syllable in r1 ('byung) is apparently a later addition by a different hand, on which a round vermilion seal (i.e., a private seal) is affixed. The inverted line on recto, the beginning of another letter to'Phan-gzigs, is crossed out. Three creases indicate that the letter was once folded into a long slip. V1 is the form of address of the recto letter. On verso there is another line written upside down by a different hand, on which one or two vermilion seals are affixed. V1(inv) suggests that this petition was used, after being endorsed and given an official seal, as a new copy of a decree given to the office of the general in Khotan, under whom the petitioners must have served as soldiers. It also indicates that the general, the head of the military district government (khrom) in the Khotan area, resided not inM.Tāghbut in'U-ten, i.e., Khotan.

msItem.type: document, a drawing of horses, a drawing of a person and a camel

note.p: r drawing + 5, v blank; r drawing, v blank

Frag. a (mistakenly tagged b. in Plates) contains a drawing of three horses. Text (r1) suggests that the drawing was donated byRtsang rmang-rogs.rmang-rogsmay mean "a horse-attendant."'don-po(r2) may read'dron-po"traveller."rgya-drug"Chinese and Türks" appears in r4. R5 is written below the drawing. Frag. b. (tagged a. in Plates) contains a drawing of a person probably leading a camel. The frags. were obtained by the third expedition and published in, but they have not been located either in the British Library or in the British Museum.

msItem.type: document, list of watchmen; table of Tibetan alphabets

note.p: Five pieces. Four small frags., once pasted on the larger frag., were separated during the conservation process. They contain the same writing, but their relative position is not clear. Recto lists names of Khotanese watchmen posted in eachtshar. On verso is a table of the Tibetan alphabets. Note that the characterbais inserted betweenlaandsha. Below the table is another line of scribbling. Also, a line of very faint writing is visible near the bottom edge, but too faint to ascertain whether it is Tibetan or Brahmi. Cf. Texts 63, 134, 164, 247, and 278.
r 6?, v blank; r 2?, v blank

msItem.type: Buddhist text, dhāraṇi or mantra, Tantric?; divination with dice?

note.p: r 6, v blank; r 9, v blank

Two frags. bear the same site number. According to Francke, they were previously pasted to one another, but their relative position is unknown. Possibly written by the same hand, they are not likely to form a single piece. Smaller frag. (text a) speaks of the banning by mantra of eating evil foods, such as arrow-pierced foods (mda's-pa?), blood (khrag), marrowbones (rkang), flesh (sha), fat (tshil), impurities (myi-gtsang-ba), etc. Larger frag. (text b) contains combinations of small circles, suggesting divination with dice, but the text, written in verse, is illegible in parts.

Recto is a complete letter fromYang-zigsto nephew (tsha-bo)Ma-brtsan. Writing is worn out, especially r3–r5. On verso is another letter by a different hand fromStag-bzangtozhangThig(?) rgyal-'jams. The right and bottom edges are cut off, showing that verso was written before recto.

note.p: Currently missing but registered in Francke, stating: "Small fr. of paper document, with a portion of 1 line, writing on one side only. The word'A-sang(perhaps a name) is all that remains. 33/4 x 3 cm."

Unfinished letter petition from a Khotanesemngan"finance official"Li bu-god; nearly complete except that the addressee's name, probably a higher ranking official, is yet to be entered at the beginning. Though the letter seems not to have been sent, there are creases indicating that it was once folded. Describes problems (= shortages) that occurred while collecting barley from a group (tshan) of priests, and requests to issue an order to convey [the barley] directly toM.Tāgh.sang(r2, r3, r4) may readstsang"grain";'bar(r2, r7) should readbar.

note.p: Recto is a letter fromSrin-dugtojo-coStag-bzher.pho-[bra(r2) may readpho-nya"envoy." The sender is asking for security against robbers whom he is afraid to meet on the road (r3–r4).spu-rtags"hair feature" is described in r4–r5. Verso seems to be a note, stating "Sum-pa gsas-slebs, a relative ofCo-ro zhang-legsin Khotan, was questioned and taken tozhang-lonofficials for examination."span(v1) should readspyan. A round vermilion seal seems to exist at the beginning of r1 and v2.

note.p: FromLegs-tshantojo-cho blonLeg-bzang. The form of address (r1) is followed by an inquiry after the addressee's health (r2). The letter concludes with a request to accept a gift of five bolts of paper sent toGling-bzher, probably a relation or retinue of the addressee (r2–r3). A round vermilion seal is visible in the middle of r1.

gi zha snga nas snyun gzhes sam ma bzhes / mcid yi ge las snyun gsol zhing mchis / skyes gyI mtshan shog
shog yug lnga zhig / gling bzher la / bskur zhing mchis na bzhes par chi gnang / * *

note.p: Upper left portion of a letter fromKlu-gzigstoStag-bzher, an official inShing-shan. A female nameKhri-ma-lodis mentioned (r1). Verso is the form of address, written on the folded letter.

Middle portion. R2 mentionsnyin mtshan"day [and] night"; r3–r4 seem to mention "if [he] has not gone at a certain time."skyel-pa"to transport" in r5. A line in red ink appears at the left bottom corner.

Right half of a letter fromKhar-longtojo-coRgya. R2 seems to say "as for those (rmamsforrnams?) who sent letters to the district government (gromforkhrom?), they were dispatched toRngo-nam-shi." R5–r6 are greetings. R7 and the missing last line seem to say "Please send a pair of something [to?] thespāofficial (spa-safor Khot.spā?)." Form of address on verso.
Right half. Form of address is missing due to paper damage.
Middle portion; possibly a draft. Writing faint. The inverted line is probably scribbling.

FromDvang-rtonaddressed to more than 14 persons, includingLegs-kri,Si-bzher, andYul-zigs(r1–r2). R3–r4 are greetings;Mang-brtsanandLegs-snangare said to be in poor health.rgya'-ras"Chinese cotton?" andrgyu-ras"raw cotton?" appear in r6. Lower part torn off.

note.p: Middle right portion.men-tri"glossed silk cloth" is mentioned twice. R3 gives the date.'am-gra"phonetic rendering of a Chinese officialya-ya{CH}{CH}?" appears in r4.
Left portion. R1 mentions the enemy or military official (dgrafordgra-dpon) ofShing-shan. On verso lower part of probably a Tibetan character is visible (not included in Plates).

note.p: Text ends in the middle of r3, suggesting that it is a draft. R1–r3 seem to say "On the first day of the last spring month, when the military officialBtsan-basent an army,Myang lha-mthonghumbly requestsKhor-zhag." On verso only signs of the beginning of a text are written.

note.p: Right portion. Smudged and partly burnt; similar in style to Texts 63–65. List of personal names (e.g.,Myang khu-'phanandLi wi-ne-sa) together withsdeandtshar(e.g.,tsharGo-sto) to which they belong. Cf. Texts 63, 122, 134, 247, and 278.
A letter fromRind nyu-antojo-boMan-sag. Lower right portion is torn off. Remaining text mostly consists of stereotyped greetings.

note.p: Right half of an oblong sheet. R1 mentions date andbya-rta"a kind of horse(?)" of [the] year [in]Shing-shan."momay mean "divination." A horse from Khotan seems to be mentioned in r2. Text ends in the middle of r2, suggesting that this is a draft.
Lower middle portion.Rmang(r1) is probably part of the sender's name.Bun-har(r3) may be another personal name.
Lower portion. R2 is a greeting. Probably a letter draft or scribbling.

] zhal mcal gyi bar du thugs bde bar

note.p: Drawing depicted in red lines. Similar to Text 323 verso.
Middle portion. There appears to be a round vermilion seal at the top.
Only one line is partly legible; contains the wordrgyos"united in sexual embrace." On verso traces of a few syllables, may bepa'andgnyis, are partly legible (not included in Plates).

msItem.q: ] [mo (/so)] rgyos te khrI dang gI ste [

note.p: Recto and verso are written by the same hand, but probably two different contracts. Both texts end in the middle of the paper. R1 mentions "the first winter month of the horse year"; r2 contains "the middle winter month."mde'u"small arrow" appears in r3 and r5. V2 mentions "mirror of a post-runner(?)." A finger-seal is partly visible to the right of the last line on verso.Go-tha(v4) is probably an error forkhong-ta"debtor."

Text left unfinished in the middle of r4; apparently a draft. Seems to say "In the winter of the horse year, whenblonKlu-sgraet al. convoked an assembly atShel-than,Myang lha-mthong[of] theYang-rtsangdistrict demanded as interest fromLi bta(/bat)-nag, a trooper(?) of the Khotanese ruler, two bolts ofmen-trisilk on the 23rd of the first winter month of this year." There are a few misspellings:chugs-pafortshugs-pa,tshasfortshes.

la / / yang rtsang gI sde myang lha mthong lI rje 'I chugs pa lI [bta (/bat)] nag men trI

d[u] / 'tsha' de skyed gyi * * *

note.p: Nearly complete except for the left edge. Addressed toKhri-bzher,Rgyal-bzher, and'Brig-bzher. The sender's name is missing except for the last syllblesgra (/sa)in r2. Having taken to the road, the sender requests beverages be sent. Text continues from recto to verso. Several goods and animals are mentioned; they areli-dngul"silver metal or Khotanese silver" (v1), onehin(Chin.{Ch}) of wool (v2),ba-bong"cow and ass" (v3), barley (v3, v5), sixtysrangofmar"butter?" (v4), etc. Writing very indistinct and difficult to read in parts.

Recto is a personal correspondence fromzhang"uncle"Legstotsa-bo"nephew"Bzang, stating that he is sending a robe viaPhyi-mthong, probably a carrier. On verso there remain the last three lines of a letter fromGzhams zla-gong. The blank space is crossed out by oblique lines, suggesting that it is not a draft. Recto was apparently written after verso was discarded.

note.p: Right half of a letter fromPan-rmaregarding trade and payment.men-trisilk is mentioned in r5. "The middle winter month" (r7) may be the time of payment. On verso there is only one syllable by the same hand as recto; probably a part of the form of address or instructions for delivery.

Recto is the upper left portion of a letter addressed to LordKhri-mnyenandKhri-bzher. Sender's name is missing due to paper damage. Verso is the lower portion of probably a letter from'Pan-legs; threebreof millet is mentioned. A trace of a round vermilion seal appears near the left bottom.

Recto is the upper right portion of a letter fromMdo-rton(?). Verso, apparently written by the same hand, is probably the form of address.Mang-kharmay be the addressee. There is another line near the bottom edge, but too faint to read.

Upper portion (left half torn off, right edge cut off) of a letter fromSprang-re.phran-las(r3) should readphrin-las"work (respectfully)." R8 may be the end of the letter. The line on verso is probably the form of address.

Upper left portion. Sent fromLegs-zigsas a memorandum or list of goods (bsnyel-byang) of LordStag stsang-bzher. R1–r2 mention "Given an order not to fail to go there, I arrived atTshal-byiand killedmdzo,g.yag, and whatever [cattle] there were." Text continues to verso and ends in v7, followed by traces of a few round vermilion seals. V4 says "I was given a sword." V5 has "[I was] given an order not to fail to come up [with] medicine."

note.p: Middle portion of a letter fromLegs-bzangto LordCung. Onesrangof silver is mentioned in r3. Verso is different; not clearly legible, but likely the upper middle portion of a contract. The place nameShing-shanappears in v1; sixkhalof wheat in v3. Recto was probably written after verso.

Two frags. have been joined together during the conservation process. The joined ms. is the upper right portion of probably a loan contract.man-trI(r1) must be a variant spelling formen-tri, "a kind of silk cloth."Ne-tsug(r5) seems to be the debtor.

Left, right, and bottom edges cut off. R1 says "on the 20th of the last [autumn? month], having assembled the soldiers of the great administration." R2 says "Stag klu-bzherandblonNyal-tshugsrecruited soldiers." A drummer (rnga-po?)Dkog-nyal-tshugand a soldier-tablet (so-byang) appear in r3. R4 seems to say "[blonMtsho]-bzang went toShing-shan." Mt.Yol-ba-riappears in r5. On verso is the beginning of the date "winter month," probably by the same hand as recto.

Lower left portion; probably the ending part of a contract.Li ku-limay be one of the witnesses. A finger-seal ('dzub-tshad) is partly visible in r2(inv) with a short vertical line near the right edge. Another inverted line must be part of another document. On verso a few characters, such asg,d, andgs, seem legible.
Upper middle portion.la-reseems to be part of the sender's name. R2 may mean "while half of the soldiers alternate."
Lower middle portion. R2 mentionsmchId"letter"; r3 containssmon-lam. There is a blank space below r4.

Upper left portion of a dispatch fromRmang-mthungtoGung-bzher rmang-la-pan.'o-skol gnyis"we two" appears in r2. R3 quotes the utterance "Bring to me the wage (klaforgla) [for hiring] young asses." R3–r4 seem to describe the wage of carrying something to Lord someone.

Upper right portion. The form of address is missing due to paper damage. The remaining text contains greetings only.
Middle portion.sug-rgya"private seal" is mentioned in rl. R2 contains letter type 3 greetings.

note.p: Recto is a letter fromLha-'tsho. Verso is another document; three personal names are legible. Only the beginning two lines remain on each side.

Upper portion of probably a letter. Faint and hardly legible.Rgyal-to-re dpal-chu[ng?]et al. seem to be the addressees. Personal names likely to appear areLegs-mthong,Khri-bzher,Mang-sbra(?), andPan-ra. The line on verso is probably the form of address.

msItem.q: ] khri bzher dang mang s[bra --] phan ra las [-]stsogs * *

note.p: Lower(?) middle portion. Only r2 is partly legible as "at a time, thereafter."

(illegible)
]dus na slan cad [

note.p: Middle portion. Writing on both sides by the same hand.
Middle portion of probably a letter.'ba-shigmay be a personal or place name, most probably the phonetic rendering from Chinese. Verso may be the form of address of the recto letter.
Many pieces of probably a letter. Badly damaged and brittle. Only a few syllables in r3–r6 are legible.
Writing very faint on both sides. Recto seems to be a letter to LordLha-dpal(writtenlhad pal). On verso there are two personal names by a different hand from recto. They are crossed out.
Upper middle portion. R1 seems to state the assembly ('dun-tsa) and its convokers ([lastsogs]-pas). R2 mentions "midday" (gdugs). Possibly the beginning of a contract or legal document.

msItem.q:
] pas 'dun tsa [
] gdugs [

note.p: Upper middle portion. R1 gives names of convokers of thekhromassembly. R4 and r5 suggest that this is a contract for the sale of a horse. Two large red spots cover some part of the text.
Upper middle portion of a letter addressed toKlu-bzangand [the sender's] elder sisterGtsug-ldem stang-sbyal. R2 is greetings. R4 seems to be the end of the letter.

Three pieces contain Tibetan; the other is blank. The upper two pieces in Plates are apparently from the same document, but no substantial phrase can be made out. The lowest piece contains two round vermilion seals and part of a finger-seal; so the four pieces may be frags. of a contract.
Upper middle portion. Only two names,blonKhri-bzherandKo-sheng, are legible.
Lower right or middle portion. The form of address is missing. There is a blank space below r4.
Left portion; possibly an economic document. R1 gives dates, "the middle autumn month and last autumn month." R2 mentions "received atShing-shan."

Recto is probably the ending of the last line of a letter. R2 seems to say "Report [to]Sum-pa pang-kro!" Verso may be the beginning of another letter by a Khotanese official with the titlespa, or may be the form of address of the recto letter.

The same document continues from recto to vero. The beginning (upper edge of recto) and the end (lower edge of verso) have been torn off.mnganofficial andmen-trisilk appear in r3. R4–r5 say "Hereafter a vest and blanket should be delivered to each trooper of the Khotanese king."spang-[phrang](r6) may bespan-spun? Three or more round vermilion seals are affixed on verso.

note.p: Recto is a letter fromLha la-rton. Verso appears to be another letter, but is very faint; v1 gives the form of address; and greetings are partly legible in v2–v5, but difficult to read.

Middle portion.zhal-mchu"lawsuit" is mentioned in r3, but too fragmentary for further identification. On verso there are two or three lines of writing, seemingly by the same hand as recto; very faint and not clearly legible, except for a few syllables such asla,dang, andpho.

msItem.type: document; Chinese Buddhist text on verso

note.p: Two lines of Tibetan on recto. Only one personal nameMtsho-bzangcan be made out. On verso six Chinese characters are partly visible, but only two characters,{CH}and{CH}, are legible; probably a Buddhist text of some kind. Listed as C 124 in Appendix to: 265, where the site number is wrongly given as M.T. iv. 00163.

] mtsho b[zang?] gi [
(illegible)

note.p: Left half of a letter fromDu dun-skyestozhang-zhang blonKhri-bzherandnang-rje-poLha-bzang. The sender's name,Du dun-skyes, is visible on verso as part of the form of address. Place names in the Khotan area,Zhugs-ngam,'U-ten, andPe'u-tse, are mentioned. The letter seems to talk of a situation in which the sender wishes his military duty of hill stationing (ri-zug?) to be changed due to illness, and begs for generosity from the addressees.

note.p: Right portion. Personal names, such asLha-bzher,Brtsan-zigs, andMang-'od, are legible. Traces of red colour appear on r3; perhaps of a vermilion seal.

Middle portion. Place names, such asShing-shandand'U-ten, appear;bro-nad"illness" is mentioned in r6; the titledmag-pon"general" in r9. Verso is written by the same hand as recto; probably the form of address.

Lower portion. Content of the contract is missing due to paper damage. Top right corner of an upside-down finger-seal partly appears. The inverted line, part of the date, seems to be the unfinished beginning of another contract.

Right half. A large blank space appears above r1. There seem to be traces of a few round vermilion seals, but too faint to ascertain.Dur-ya(r2) andPe'u-tse(=rte; r4) are place names.rgong(r2) may readrgod. In r5–r6 the sender asks to borrow a female camel.

Lower? middle portion.Li sa'-grum(r2) may be a personal name. R3 says "having thus decided." A finger-seal is partly seen below r5. On verso a few unconnected characters are visible, but cannot be made out.
Only a few characters on both sides, apparently written by the same hand. Only the wordmchiscan be made out in r1. May be from the same document as Text 220.
Upper middle portion. R1 says "in the presence of [someone] residing"; r2 mentions "letter"; r3 speaks of either "becoming ill" or "taking an oath." There is a blank space below r3.

Lower middle portion. Only a few syllables on both sides, apparently written by the same hand. The phrase[']dzub-tshad-gyiscan be made out on recto; verso has only the syllabletshal. This may be from the same document as Text 218.

Four small frags. are placed together. Two contain Tibetan; apparently from the same document, but only a few unconnected syllables can be made out. One of the other two is coloured yellow and contains a few Brahmi-like characters. The last frag. has faint traces of a drawing or writing.

Upper left portion; the left edge remains partly in r4. R1 gives the date; r2 mentionsdgra'-blon"military official." R3 states "[should the debtor] fail to repay or [should] there be any shortage." The substantial part of the contract is missing. Two lines of previously unpublished Khotanese appear on verso.

Two frags. have been joined together. The bottom edge is missing, but the blank space in r2 suggests that r2 is the end of the text. Seems to be a list of names with the amount ofmen-trisilk [loaned?] to each person: Oneyugofmen-trieach toLi byi-de,Klu-'tsho, andWang mdo-gzigs.

msItem.type: divination by dream; Chinese Buddhist text on verso

note.p: Two frags. have been joined together. The reconstructed text is still incomplete, much smudged and not clearly legible. It is likely to be a divination by dream (cf. Pelliot 55). The Tibetan text is written on the back side of a Chinese text (959and960). The reconstructed Chinese text (16 ll.) is a frag. of{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH} {CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}(Saddharmapuṇdarīka, Chap.6,Vyākaraṇa), which corresponds tovol. 9: 21c, ll.2–22.

msItem.type: Buddhist text, transliteration of Chinese; Chinese Buddhist text on verso

note.p: A line of Tibetan is written on the back side of a Chinese sutra (961). Begins with "In the Chinese (or Indian) language"; the ensuing seven syllables seem to be a phonetic transliteration of Chinese; may contain characters such as,{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}, but not definitely ascertainable. Two syllables of Tibetan are written on verso in the bottom margin of the Chinese text, also likely a phonetic rendering of Chinese.

Writing on both sides; r1–r7 rather faint; from r8 on more distinct with a different pen;gden-pho-led(v8) by a different hand. A monogram in r1. Traces of two or three round vermilion seals in v8. There is a line of horizontally-cut slits ofca. 1 cm long near the right and left edges.

note.p: Recto is a letter fromLha-ri-skyestoRgyal-bzher. The address is written by another hand upside down in the lower space, probably after the letter was folded.sos-kyi(r3) may mean "for cure, medical treatment." Verso is the lower part of a document by a different hand from recto regarding an arrangement of soldiers or guards (cf. Texts 63, 82, 122, 134, and 164). The top and bottom edges are cut off; the paper with the verso text was cut and used to write the recto letter.

note.p: Right portion. R1 says "at the time when[. .]r-nyinwas at'U-ten." R2 mentions "among the fifteen Chinesebre[of grain]." R3 says "in case they were sold." R4 contains "to be offered tozhang-po dgra-blonLha-bzher." Text ends with a greeting (r5). A large vermilion seal is affixed at the right bottom corner. Three syllables separately appear on verso; may be the form of address written after the paper was folded.

The beginnng part, the form of address, is missing due to paper damage. R3–r4 contain greetings. R5 continues to v1–v2, stating the delivery of a gift, asking for notice in case of non-delivery, and acknowledging the addressee's cordial acceptance of the gift. V3 is probably part of the form of address; only the last syllable of the addressee's namestois legible.

Upper middle portion. R1–r4 are the form of address and greetings. Personal names, such asLegs-kong(r5),Sha-myi lha-srong(r6), andMdo-bzher(r7), are mentioned. R6 contains "fourbreof barley." Verso is another letter or document by another hand.
A wide blank space appears above the text. R2 is the end of the text, which seems to say "please submit toDbrongs." Four vertical lines appear at the right bottom corner.

Upper left portion. Right half and lower half torn off. FromRmang-rogs(cf. Text 96) toKha-ga pan-khri. After greetings (r2), the sender, a horse-attendant, seems to speak of troubles (or family reasons) which hindered his work (r3–r6); a lawsuit was filed on his behalf by the lady's servants (r6–r7). R10–r11 say that the wage ofMe-nu nya-gzigs, a subject ofzhangRgyal-bzher, was raised from sevenzhoto fourteen.

note.p: Six frags. are placed together. Two frags. each with 5 and 3 lines are apparently from the same document, probably a letter (00123. a. = Text 271). Two frags. with very faint writing belong to another document (00123. b. = Text 272). Still another two frags. contain no text (00123. c. = Text 273). Two frags. of Text 271 cannot be joined together, but their relative position can be decided: one forms the middle left part and the other forms the bottom part. A total of eight lines are visible, but only a few syllables, such aspa nI ma-mchi,bka'"order,"gda',yang, andsmon-cing-mchis"[I am] praying," are legible.

Two frags. contain part of a drawing or large characters. See Text 271.

Torn in several places with many holes. FromGsas-slebstozhang-po'Phan-bzher. Sent together with gifts of three kinds of medicine and a pair of cotton tents (r11). The line on verso is the form of address, where the addressee bears the titledgra-blon.

note.p: Upper right portion. FromCung-bzangtonang-poSnang-bzherandMdo-bzher. R2–r4 are mostly greetings. The two addressees are referred to asnang-pho (=po) cagin r3.nang-pomay benang-rje-po. Verso is the form of address.

Left half of a petition to four officials (ra-sangs-rje,mngan,dgra-blon, andspa). R4 mentions "we also are short of provisions." Verso is the left half of another letter by a different hand addressed to LordKhong-bzang. (tshes nyi-shu"the 20th day" occurs both in r5 and v2.) V3 seems to say "[the sender] fell ill." Trace of probably a large vermilion seal. Below v5 there is an inverted line which reads "Sent to thertse-rjeofficial inShing-shan."

note.p: Originally folded, as shown in the plate in, where recto was folded inside. But recto is graffiti consisting of curses onnang-rje-poBtshan-do-re, while verso is a letter fromMkhar-slebsto Lord'An-mdzes.ssal(v2) is written forstsal;'defor'di(v3);'pangsfor'bangs(v3);pa's la(v4) forpa las. R5 and r1(vert) may be the form of address of the verso letter. Since the lower half of v5 is torn off, verso was written before recto. Possibly the recto graffiti were written on the back of the verso letter, then the paper was folded just like a letter.

Four frags. of the same ms. Two very small pieces, one at the upper left and the other at the lower left, were separated from a larger frag. during the conservation process. In all only a few characters are visible; the wordbreappears, suggesting that this is a document concerning grain.

Two frags. have been joined together, but there still remain gaps in some of the lines. The reconstructed text is a letter toRgyal-bzherandCung-ra. Verso is another letter fromLegs-tshan(?) andGye'u-chungtoBtshan-zigs; unfinished in the middle of v7. Very faint and indistinct (esp., r5–r7); difficult to attempt a reading with certainty. A large trace of vermilion ink near the right edge.

note.p: A letter fromKhrom-legstoStag-bzang. Lower part torn off. Note the negative clausesthugs myi bde(r1) andmyi dga' zhing(r2), not commonly used in greetings. The Tibetan text was written apparently after the Khotanese text on verso. For the Khotanese, see5:222,Pl. LXIX, (LVIII), and79–80. Another very small frag. with a few Tibetan characters (gi',shIng) was put in the same plate (=Khotanese Plate 54).

note.p: Right half of a letter fromBzu-ru; the adressee's name is missing. Right edge is also torn off, but in each line only one or two characters are probably missing. Blank space below r7. R2 mentions the date "winter month" and the place nameShu-lig"Kashgar"; r4 reads "went to'U-tenon the 15th of the middle [month]." Personal names, such asLod-ltong chung-kong-slebsandKugs 'phan-legs, are found. Verso is another letter, addressed to LordStag-bzher; the sender's name is missing.

Lower portion; the first two lines seem to be missing. Badly damaged with many holes. R2–r3 are greetings. Names and titles, such asKlu-gzigs,rtse-rje,Snang-sgra,Snya-don gsas-sbyin,Mdo-bzang, andMu-ryo-ce, appear.bya chen-mo"big birds" and 900 copper coins are mentioned. A round vermilion seal is affixed at the right bottom corner; asvastikaand a name, which seems to readbzang, appear. Verso may be a continuation from recto, but extremely faint and hardly legible. V2 hasgya-gyu bgyi"to make intrigues," a common phrase in contracts.

Upper left corner. The addressee's name may be reconstructed asblonDgra-bzher. Another personal nameThod-dar bzang-poseems to appear in r3.

FromChas-legsto LordMtsho-bzangandKlu-mnyen. After the greeting (r1–r2), r2–r4 seem to say "If I do not descend the mountain in the last winter month, it is no good. If the provisions of'Phan-bzherwere not received previously, please receive them." The letter ends with the wish for the addressees' well-being.

Lower right corner of probably a contract for borrowingdong-tshe"copper coins." A round vermilion seal is visible at the left bottom corner. Published in Contracts.

There is a blank space below r12. R6 mentionsDbrad(?) snang-lod, a bondservant ofzhangLang-lon. "The official duty (rje-blas) of the sender" appears in r9. Since Francke mentions the existence of 19 or 20 lines, the upper 7 or 8 lines seem to have been torn off since then.

Middle portion. Only a few unconnected syllables, such aspa niandkyi, are legible.
Upper middle portion. Only a few syllables are legible in each line.
Upper right corner. No personal names remain. Francke states that there are two Chinese characters on verso, and traces can be discerned, but they are too indistinct to ascertain.

Five small frags. of possibly the same document have been placed together. A few unconnected syllables, such asmg[o?],sde che, andsogs, are found on three of them. Too fragmentary for further identification.

Frag. of a Buddhist text written on both sides of probably a pothī folio. Writing in an ornamental style, probably of the late Old Tibetan period. A small frag. with a few characters on both sides has apparently been detached from the same folio.
Two frags. (Samp. 040. and Samp. unnumbered) have been joined together.bka'-lung"command" seems to appear in r3. The drawing in red on verso may be a part of a wheel.

Middle portion. Speaks ofbyan-po"cook" (r1),tshal-ma"provisions" (r1 and r3), andnyIn-ra"day encampment" (r2). Six characters are visible on verso, probably written by a different hand from recto. Writing is very faint and hardly legible.
Left portion of possibly a letter. May be from the same document as Text 326.

note.p: Fifteen small frags. were placed in one sack. No site number is written on any of the pieces. The note enclosed in the sack simply reads "Dom." One frag. seems to contain Uighur script, but too fragmentary to ascertain. The other fourteen frags., labelled a. through n. (Texts 333–346) in the present catalogue, contain Tibetan. Of these, Text 342 has a Chinese character on verso. All the Tibetan texts appear to be letter frags., but they do not seem to form one piece. Text 333 is the upper left corner of a letter. The blank space below r4 indicates that it is the last line of the letter.

Upper? middle portion. Paper seems to have been partly burned. It was placed with seven Sanskrit frags. in a sack. The note contained in the sack designates the site numbers Khad. 029. 1. through 8., but the numbers are not written on the frags. Stein describes Khad. 029. as "This packet contains only small frs., often much crushed, of at least 8-9MSS. Writing generally of Brahmi script, but in some cases appears to be different. The frs. are so small that nothing definite seems dicoverable. Some frs. show traces of fire." (1021)
r complete, v frag (L, R, B)

Recto is a complete contract, as described in. It was written after the verso document was discarded. Verso is the lower part of probably a letter. The upper edge is cut off. Text is unfinished. Consecutive dates such as, "16th, 17th, 18th, 20th, 23rd, 27th days," can be made out. Since writing is extremely faint, the reading given here remains tentative. Acquired by Stein through Badruddīn Khān together with Sanskrit and Khotanese texts during his third expedition. The Sanskrit and Khotanese mss. (Khad. 04-20, 038-051) are listed in1021,1022,1027, but there is no mention of Khad. 052.

msItem.type: document, letter draft; Chinese Buddhist text; Khotanese on verso, Chinese-Tibetan-Khotanese

note.p: One line of Tibetan, a scribal exercise of the forms of address, is written in the bottom margin of a Chinese Buddhist text. Note that the sender's name precedes that of the addressee's. Verso is a Khotanese Buddhist text (see3:128–129. Ms. was originally part of a long scroll together with Kha. i. 221; Stein states, "As if to illustrate further the polyglot character of Khotan Buddhism, a line in Tibetan, too, appears at the bottom of the smaller of the two roll pieces, Kha. i. 221." (164,1445). The Chinese text, described as C 47 in Appendix to: 251, is part of the{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}(Mahā-parinirvāṇa sūtra), vol. 9:vol. 12: 4209a10–b10.

msItem.q: /./ chi[g po blo]n gnyan hum gyis / * * / stag dpal gyi rgyal mtshan la gsol ba / / ban de thugs rtag [du] bde * * *

note.p: Four frags. of probably a letter. Only the largest frag. contains substantial text, as given here, where a Khotanese officialspaYan-beris mentioned (r4). Nine frags. of document with Khotanese and cursive Gupta, numbered Kha. vi. 14 b., are mentioned in160,1446. Although the Tibetan text Kha. vi. 14. a. is not explicitly mentioned, it must have been excavated at the same time and place during Stein's second expedition.

note.p: Contains traces of three or four characters, such aslaandga; very faint and illegible. Since it has been placed with other paper documents, its material has been considered to be paper; but it is actually a very thin (less than 1 mm) piece of wood. The ms. should therefore be re-registered in the forthcoming catalogue of wooden slips.

Contains two different documents, one on each side. Recto is middle portion of probably a letter. On verso only a few phrases, such as "threezho[of grain]" (v2) and "hereafter" (v4), can be made out. There seems to be a faint trace of a vermilion seal.

Upper middle portion. Paper badly damaged with many holes. The end of r1 hassngar /"in the presence [of]," suggesting a type 3 letter. Also mchis (r3),bu-lon"loan, debt" (r4),nas(r5), andrgya nas(r6) can be made out.

Placed with eleven Khotanese mss. in a plate. The slip attached to the plate states "Documents found by Altan Khan near Khadalik site [space] Keriya 14/4/24." R1 mentions a well-known temple in'Gu-zhan:[gtsug]-lag-khang'Gu-zhan.

Two small frags., each containing only a few syllables. The larger one has the beginning of probably a letter draft on recto (ra1). There seem to be a few Tibetan characters on verso, but too faint to ascertain. The smaller piece is probably part of another letter (rb1–3); unidentified scribbling on verso. Since no site numbers are written on them, the site number for each frag. cannot be specified, except that they belong to between Har. 072. 12. and Har. 072. 19., as designated by the attached slip. For the site number Har., see Introduction and1051–56

Upper left corner. Text begins with the date "tiger year"; r3 containsgla"wage," and r2 mentions "two days." These suggest that it may be a hire contract similar to Text 675. This frag. was placed with three Sanskrit frags. in a sack with a note designating site numbers Har. 079. 16 through 19. For the site number Har., see Introduction and IA: 1051–56.

msItem.type: document, register, name list of Khotanese priests; Khotanese on verso

note.p: A complete Tibetan document written on the back side of a Khotanese text. The text mostly consists of a name list, where sixteen seemingly Khotanese priests are named under a unit [headed by] Great priestStagyi rgyal-mtshan(r2–r6). They seem to have been responsible for paying barley duty imposed on the unit. The barley serves as a fee for caring for an official,blonRgyal-bzang, while he was ill (r1–r2). A priest,Nog-su ber-zha, collected and forwarded the barley (r6–r7). This interpretation, however, is tentative. Note several uncommon spellings, e.g.,stagyi(r2) andtsadzugo(r6). Both the Tibetan and Khotanese texts have been published in; Khotanese text in2:68. No site number is indicated on the ms. The Khotanese text suggests its provenance to be the area of "Six Towns" east of Khotan.

note.p: Badly damaged paper with many holes; several holes seem to have been cut intentionally. Writing on both sides is faint and not clearly legible. Recto seems to be a contract for the sale of a male bondservant. R1 gives the date "[In the spring?] of the sheep year when a Khotanese officialKhri-gda'mand aspyan-officialDpal-bzher, etc., convoked an assembly at'U-ten." This indicates that the document was drawn up in the Khotan area. (Khri-gda'mmight be same asKhri-gdas;44). The buyer's name is partly legible asZha-pong(r2). The seller's name is missing on recto, but there is a heading to the contract on verso (v5) which reads "The bond ofKhrom-skyes," suggesting thatKhrom-skyesis the seller. V1–v4 may be a continuation from recto, but is hardly legible. A few short lines near the recto's top edge may be the lower portions of some characters. Cf. Text 676 for the requisition number.

Recto is the lower middle portion of a Tibetan text. Only a few syllables are legible. R 2 seems to be the end of the text. On verso three lines of Khotanese are partly visible. Previously unpublished.

note.p: Lower portion of the beginning of a line. Probably the beginning of a letter. Names of the two addressees are partly legible as "LordsG.yu-bzherandKlu-bzher."

msItem.q: [/ jo co g.yu bzher dang klu bzher la /]

note.p: Middle portion. Three lines are partly legible. Words such asdka'"difficult",ston-rka"summer time(?)", andyon-tan"merit" are legible.

One line is written on a strip of paper. It reads "[This was] taken out by the request ofRo-sumofLha-sto." The note attached to this and Text 364 indicates that these two frags. were transferred from the British Museum to the India Office Library on September 30th, 1920.

msItem.q: lha sto'i ro sum zhus pas phyung ngo /

note.p: Middle portion. The palaeography and the wordbla-ma(r3) suggest that this is a Buddhist text, but is too fragmentary to identify. For its provenance, see Text 363.

Upper left portion. On recto two distinct texts are written inverted to each other. The text of 5 lines is probably a contract for loaning millet. Traces of round vermilion seals are visible to the right of r5, but too faint to count how many. The inverted text also speaks of payment ('bul-bar,ring), but is not likely to be a contract. Verso mentions millet as well, but too indistinctive for further identification.

Recto is a letter fromStag-legsto blonSkyes-bzang. The right bottom corner has been cut off to 2.5 x 15.5 cm as a tally; the upper part of a few oblique lines appear above the cut off. The letter concerns the sending of medicine, an excuse for the delay, and instructions on how to take the medicine. Verso is another letter petition from the people of Lang clan (lang-myi) toGung khrI-bzher. The first three lines are partly cut off. Below the text another line is written upside down, probably the form of address of the petition. The whole text is crossed out with oblique lines in order to write another letter on recto.

note.p: Upper middle portion of probably a letter toblonLegs-bzangandblonRma-. It ends at v8, below which there is a blank space. Place names, such asKlu-rtse(r14),Nob-shod(v3), andNob chu-ngu(v6), appear.Mdo-sgra(r13) seems to be a personal name. The beginning of a line, probably the form of address of another letter, is written below the space upside down.

msItem.type: Buddhist text with dhāraṇi or mantra, Tantric?

note.p: Upper middle portion of a Buddhist text, mostly mantras. Writing style is similar to Text 372, but they are probably different texts.

msItem.type: document, loan contract; calligraphic exercise or divination?

note.p: Recto is the upper right corner of a contract for loaning barley. R1–r3 mention "when [we] counted the provisions, there was great shortage of barley; so it was decided to loan the barley." R7 gives the date "middle spring month of the ox year." On verso are six lines of calligraphic writing, with short phrases regardingngo"side,prospect" written between the lines. The phrases, such assnying-dga'-ba'i ngo,ngo-bzang,grog-kyi ngo,skug-bla,bla-phyugs, suggest that verso is a kind of divination, but may be scribbling.

msItem.type: document concerning the assignment of ranks (yi-ge)

note.p: Three frags. have been joined together to form a single piece. The joined paper still lacks its right edge. The text is probably a report or request concerning the assignment of ranks to local officials of the district calledSka-ba bong-yul. Titles such as,gser-gyi yi-ge ched-po,dngul-gyi yi-ge ched-po, andzangs-gyi yi-ge, and names of officials are found. The text likely continues from recto to verso, and ends at v7 with the phrasedgod-pa[r] gsol"[I thus humbly] request to issue," leaving the lower part blank. Writing on verso is faint and hardly legible, except for a few personal names, includingStag-gtsug-bzhe[r]andLha-dpal-stag.

note.p: Two frags. have been joined together. The reconstructed text is near the last part of theĀrya-Aparimitāyur-nāma-sūtra. Corresponds with minor differences to a Dunhuang text P[elliot] 105, ll. 92–99. Apparently a different ms. from Texts 550–553.

Middle portion. Recto may be a contract for loaning grain. R1 says "Having made an advance loan [of] grain."'Ba' khva-hva(r3) seems to be a personal name. Verso may be a letter, but is crossed out by oblique lines.
Upper middle portion. Recto is a letter, and verso is probably another letter.

Upper left portion. Recto is the beginning of a letter fromSam-spestoTor leg-snedand'Ji-rma. Verso is apparently distinct from recto, probably a legal document. The lower part of another line is seen above v1. V1 says "humbly requested to the assembly ofdmag-ponandspyanofficials." V2–v4 are smaller characters and more faint than v1. Four round vermilion seals are visible below v4.

msItem.type: document with drawing of a circle, horoscope?, divination?

note.p: Part of a drawing of a large circle with many radii and a smaller circle inside. Spaces formed by the intersection of circles and radii contain inscriptions; each space has one word, such asrug-la/,tig-li/,pya-skang/,bya-khr[,phug-[, andgnam-[. Below the drawing there are six lines, of which the first four form one paragragh. The last two are the beginning part of another paragraph or text, but very faint and not clearly legible.

msItem.type: Buddhist text, De-bzhin-gshegs-pa'i gtsug-tor gdugs dkar-po (Uṣṇīṣasitātapatranāma-dharaṇī)

note.p: Oblong sheet; most probably one folio from concertina. Recto (N.B.: recto and verso were mistakenly reversed in Plates) is the middle part of theGtsug-tor gdugs dkar-po, corresponding to Dunhuang texts: e.g., P[elliot] 23, fol.19, l.3–fol.20, l.4; P 83, column 2, 4–8 (also cf. Peking, nos. 202–205). One line of additional writing appears in the margin below r5, and a phrase is written vertically in the right margin, both by the same hand but different from the main text. Verso is another Buddhist text by the same hand as recto main text. The phrasernam-dag-zhIng der skye-bar 'gyur"will be born in the pure land" is repeated five times.

note.p: Two frags. are pieces of the same letter; M. I. iv. 90. is the left half, and M. I. iv. 93. a. is the right half, but a few characters are still missing in between. The reconstructed text, originally consisting of two lines, is a dispatch fromblonRgyal-sum-bzhertoKhrim-bzherregarding instructions to receive loaned barley.snga-skyin"advance loan" is spelledsnga-skyen(r1).

note.p: The main text continues from recto to v1, followed by two round vermilion seals. Another seal is visible on verso near the bottom edge. Three round vermilion seals are also visible on recto. This is no doubt an original document. Near the right bottom corner on recto is the beginning of a line written upside down:$ // yu, which is no doubt a mistake. On verso there is another line written upside down. It may be the document's heading. The document speaks of the division of the lord's field, the assignment of farmers to each division, and regulations and instructions to the officials in charge.

Three pieces of the same ms. Frags. c. and b. have been joined together; there is a small gap between frags. a. and c. The reconstructed text thus reunited is a nearly complete pothī folio of theSo-sor thar-pa'i mdo. The text corresponds to Stein Dunhuang texts,5(vol. 72) foll. 19b10–20a3, and8(vol. 12) foll. ka-22b2–5; also with minor differences to6(vol. 24) foll. 15[=pha]b2–16[=ba]a3,7(vol. 61) foll. 36.1–37.4, and toChe 9b5–10a4;2, 11a2–11b2. Additional glosses in smaller characters are written interlinearly. Two holes for binding are encircled in red.

note.p: Recto seems to be a register listing the names of people and their masters or heads, together with the amount of grain due to each person. Parts of r2, r3 and the middle of r6 through r7 are written in red ink. Verso is another document, but indistinct and hardly legible; thus the text is only partly given here. V11 mentions ass, ox, sheep, and horse. Certainphul"handful amounts" of barley and water are also mentioned (v17–v18). Another fragmentary sheet with five lines pasted at right angles to verso has been detached and described as Text 439.

Previously pasted on the back side of Text 438, but separated during the conservation process. Apparently different text on either side. Writing on both sides is indistinct and hardly legible. Only relatively clear and decipherable parts are given here.

msItem.type: Buddhist text, 'Phags-pa lag-na rdo-rje gos sngon-po can gyi cho-ga shes-bya-ba'i gzungs (Ārya-Nīlām baradharavajrapāṇikalpanāma-dhāraṇī)

note.p: Upper middle part of a leaf. Recto is the first half of'Phag-pa lag-na rdo-rje gos sngon-po can gyi cho-ga shes-bya-ba'i gzungs, which corresponds toBka'-'gyur, Rgyud, Da 161a8–b6.gos sngon-po canin the Bka'-'gyur text appears asgos kar-po can(r2). Verso is another Buddhist text in rather cursive and faint writing. The middle part of the lower lines is hardly legible owing to soiled paper.

Invoice from (lit. of) thekho-ngam[official]. It describes what is to be sent to whom, e.g., "threepho-reof wool toMdzes-ldan, three and a halfkhalof barley to a person ofNob ched-po, etc." (r1–r3). R3–r4 seem to say "[Of these] threepho-reof wool of'Phan-legswas left aside (i.e., undelivered) this year. The things [appearing] later should be sent without leaving [anything] aside."

msItem.type: Buddhist text, a dialogue regarding Buddhist concepts

note.p: A pothī folio; the right and left edges are torn off and the remainder damaged in parts. A circle for the hole for binding remains partly at the right end. Text on both sides consists of questions (introduced bydris-pa) and answers (bysmras-pa) about Buddhist concepts such as,sangs-rgyas,lam,bshad-pa,rig-par bgyid-pa, andrtags-pa.

Thirteen small frags. were placed together under the site number M. I. ix. 12. Ten of them (here numbered M. I. ix. 12. a. – j.: Texts 475–483) seem to be pieces from the same ms., probably a letter. Probably names of addressees are partly visible in Text 475 (r1). Text 480 mentionsdbon-sras"grandsons and sons(i.e., descendants) [of the Btsanpo]". Texts 479 and 480 contain writing on verso, most probably the form of address. Frags. i. and j. (Text 483) have been joined together.

note.p: Two frags., once glued together to form recto and verso of a large pothī with two holes for binding, have now been detached and placed on a large sheet. They are mistakenly located together with the Dunhuang mss. in volume 72. Four or five lines seem to be missing in the lower part of recto (= the upper frag. in Plates) and the upper part of verso (= the lower frag.). The back sides of the frags. seem to be blank. Lines are ruled. The title'Gyod tshangs dang smon lamis found in r1 and v2, but the text does not agree with the Dunhuang mss. bearing the same or similar title:208.2,209,210,247,452.2;,,,.

note.p: Letter or petition addressed tojo-coBtsan-nyaandKlu-sgrafromYul-mthong, asking for a receipt for payment of the annual tribute ofGreat Nob.li-bal"Khotanese wool?" is mentioned as tribute (r3);sul(r5) may be a misspelling forpul. Two round vermilion seals, probably belonging toYul-mthong, are visible. The one line on verso, saying "The annual tribute ofGreat Nobfor the mouse year," seems to be the heading to the recto text.

msItem.type: Buddhist text, Shes-rab-kyi pha-rol-tu phyin-pa'i tshul brgya-lnga-bcu-pa (Prajñāpāramitānaya-śatapañcāśatikā)

note.p: M. I. xiii. 13. a. and b. are pieces of the same ms. and have been joined together. The reconstructed text thus reunited is part of thePrajñāpāramitānayaśatapañcāśatikā. Recto corresponds to a Stein Dunhuang text,96= Ch. 9. I. 45. (vol. 42) fol. 2b6–10; also with minor differences to97(vol. 38) foll. 25b1–28b1,102(vol. 63) foll. 16a1-18a4, and to, Ta 280a3-280b2. Verso corresponds to96(vol. 42) fol. 3b3–8; and with minor differences to97(vol. 38) foll. 38a1–40b3 and toTa 281b5–282a3. Cf. Text 651.

note.p: Nine frags. were placed together under the site numbers M. I. xiii. 001. a. – i. Of these five (a. – e.) seem to be pieces of the same ms. Frags. a. and b. have been joined together as Text 494. Frags. c. and e. have been joined (Text 495). Though the two joined texts cannot be combined, their positions are relatively clear; they form the beginning part of a letter fromLha-phyugto[-]n-bzher. The reconstructed text is given here. Frag. d. is the middle left portion of the same ms.; but its relative position to Texts 495 cannot be confirmed; the text is given separately in Text 496.
skyin"loan" appears in r3. See Text 494.

note.p: Paper badly torn and damaged; writing hardly legible in parts. May have belonged to the same ms. as Texts 498 and 499, but yet to be ascertained.
Text 498 and Text 499 seem to be pieces of the same ms., but cannot be joined together. Only a few syllables, such askyang'tsha[l], are legible in Text 498.
Probably belongs to the same ms. as Text 498. Only a few syllables, such astsi,rlang gyi, andbstod, are legible.
Upper middle portion. The form of address is on verso. The addressee's name is only partly visible in r1 and also on verso.

Middle portion. Names of the addressee and sender are partly legible in r1 and v1. R3 says "[someone] goes toNob ched-po." A dispute and decision is mentioned in R4. The form of address is on verso, but not clearly legible. Creases indicate that the paper was once folded.
Upper middle portion. The first line partly reads "winter, year of [. . .],Little Nob's." Possibly the beginning of a legal text.

msItem.q: ] lo'i dgun nob cu ngu'i m[

note.p: Lower left part of a contract for loaning millet. Both the debtor's and creditor's names are missing due to paper damage; only the name of a witnessRgyal-zigsis legible in r4. The last phrase in r5 "as for the wage in barley(?)" is a rare expression in loan contracts; it may have been added due to a particular aspect of this contract. Traces of four or five vermilion seals are visible.

note.p: Three frags. are glued together. One is blank. The other two bear text, apparently belonging to the same document, a letter. The line of the right positioned piece may have been located to the left of r3 of the left positioned piece.
Probably the right bottom corner. Writing hardly legible, except forsug-rgyas"by a private seal" in r2. May be part of a contract.
Left half. One of the parties concerned is namedSnam sham-bzang. The object loaned and the name of the other party are unknown due to paper damage. Cf. Text 518.

Verso is another letter by a different hand, which shows the form of address partly, but is incomplete at the end.

Upper left corner; addressed tojo-boandMyes-rtsan. The line on verso may be the form of address, but faint and not clearly legible. A trace of a vermilion seal is visible at the left bottom corner on verso.

note.p: Lower right portion. No substantial expressions remain except forgod-rtag(r6),phrin-las(r7), andring-rab(r7). There is a blank below r7, but the sentence does not conclude at the end of r7. There must have been another short line in the currently missing part.

Left portion. The form of address is missing on recto. R2 mentions "tenkhalof wheat [and] barley as a wage toShang-zigs." R6 seems to be the last line of the letter. Verso seems to be the form of address;Tsa myi-ston(?) may be the addressee.

note.p: Probably upper part; addressed toG.yu-bzher. Only the form of address and greetings are partly visible. Text 512 is likely to be the lower part of the same letter.
Lower middle portion; probably a piece of the same letter as Text 51. Writing indistinct; only a few unconnected syllables are legible, except for r2.

Recto is nearly complete, only the right edge is missing. Possibly a contract regarding the sale of cattle(?). R1 begins with the date "spring, year of the boar," followed by two personal names,Bung klu-gzigsandThir-pul(?). A goat and a young ass are mentioned in r2 as the objects for transactions, followed by another nameDun-myi lha-bzher. R3–r4 are not clearly legible, where several characters are corrected in bold style. R3 seems to talk of sending or receiving "these men and cattle." R4 gives the names of two witnesses,'O-nal [-d-cung]andBong phrang ja-bzha'. Two round vermilion seals are visible near the bottom edge, and a faint one is visible near the right end. Verso contains the last three lines of another document, possibly a letter; apparently written before recto.

note.p: Three contracts are written on one sheet of paper. R1–r4 contain a contract for loaning [three something] bySo-ngan long-kongfrom'O-nal rkong-chung. R1(inv)–r3(inv) contain a contract for loaning barley; the beginning part is missing. Verso is the lower middle part of another contract for loaning millet.Phan-kong(v5) andLdong-kong(v9) seem to be the debtors.'O-nal lha-gong(v7) andRgyal-zigs legs-rtsan(v8) are witnesses.

The right edge is torn off. Though the top edge seems to have been torn off, the first line remains. The letter is addressed tojo-coKlu-smanfromRtsang lde-[ya]. The sender seems to explain that he was not able to see the addressee because he was interrupted atPo-gams(forMdo-gams?)Kva-cu, and requests the addressee to receive his present, onepho-reof wool.

Personal names (Spal-ba myes-slebsandStag-bzher skyi-khyugs) and place names (Ka-dagandSig-nis[forSig-nig? in the west]) are legible.stod-gyi dbang-blon"an official of the west" appears in r5. Another document on verso is crossed out by lines. V1 gives the date. V3–v5 seem to be part of a letter.

note.p: Recto and verso are probably of the same document regarding sheep and grain. Written in relatively large characters, but indistinct and faint in parts. V1 mentions "burning [something]"; v2 contains "price of a cut piece," which may be connected with "sheep" in v3. Fifteenbreof "white [wheat]" and fivebreof "black [wheat]" are mentioned as a price in v4.sman-pa"physician(?)" appears in v2.

Lower right portion. Two witnesses,Rtsig lha-rtsa-skyesandRgyal-zigs-leg, are mentioned in r1. They appear in several other texts, including Texts 506, 542, and 546.Ldong-kong(r2) may be the guarantor. He may be identical withPo (/so)-ngan ldong-kongin Text 542.

] rgya dang ldong kong s[

note.p: Only a few syllables are legible. R2 seems to mention "my knife." R3 may mean "advise to be sold." A trace of a vermilion seal is visible on verso.

note.p: Two frags. are pieces of the same letter. Verso seems to be the form of address. Either the sender or the addressee is namedblonMang-sum.
Joined with M. I. xiv. 61. e.

Recto is the upper(?) right corner of probably a letter. R1 is a greeting. R2–r10 seem to talk of buying a horse and/or horse provisions. R2 mentions "horse provisions in a well"; r3 "bought [something]; a horse, buck-wheat"; r4 "paying to the debtor." The personal name,G.yu-legs, seems to appear in r6. "Sixsrang" (r8) may be the price of a horse. It seems that the letter and the contract form one text (cf. Texts 382 and 631). Verso is probably the same text as recto, but hardly legible, except for a few words, such asdkar gnag"white and black [wheat]." A short line in smaller characters is written upside down near the bottom edge; apparently scribbling, but not legible. A trace of faint vermilion ink appears on verso.

Faint and careless writing on both sides; not clearly legible. Recto is apparenly a document. A personal name beginning withklu-appears in r2; r2 also contains "we do homage." R3 seems to say "There is no one who gives homage(?); my husband does the cooking." Verso is another document in a more careless and running style. V2 mentions "four of those which have not been sent." The date "15th of the middle spring month" appears in v3.

Recto is probably a letter. R2 seems to say, "11breand 7.5phulof barley is deficient to each [person]." R3 seems to talk of "delivering 18 [bre? of] barley and wheat which is to be delivered toDa gsas-bsang(?)."Nob ched-po"Great Nob" is mentioned in r4. R5 seems to be the end of the letter. Verso is another document concerning grain tribute.
Recto is right part of a loan contract, but its content cannot be identified from the remaining text. Only three syllables remain on verso; apparently a different document.

Recto is a letter;ltang-sbyalmay be part of the sender's (or the addressee's) name. Verso seems to be a different document. A round vermilion seal is partly visible at the upper left corner, which is followed by shad and a blank. This may be the end of a paragraph. Two more lines are visible below it, but not clearly legible.

Recto is upper left part of a document, referring to herds of sheep (lug-khyu). R4 containstshong-gi khyu"herd for sale"; r5bdagI lug-khyur"to my sheep herd"; r7 "two men." The personal nameSlung-khriappears in r2. Verso is the lower left part of a different document, but difficult to identify due to fragmentary and partly indistinctive writing.

note.p: Recto is the upper middle part of a document. R1 gives the date "on the [. . .] of the last spring month of [. . .] year." "Horse commanderRngog phyI-zigs" seems to be mentioned in r2. Upper part of a character is visible on the bottom edge, suggesting that the text continues. Verso is a different document, probably a letter of type 2. Personal names, such asLha-bzang(v1),Klu-stsol(v2), and-legs(v3), are legible. Text seems to have originally consisted of three lines. Verso must have been written after recto.
Middle part of possibly a letter. R2 says "hereafter send [something] toRgyal-po-skyong."
Only a few syllables remain.myi-'pham"not subdued" (r2) may be a personal name.

Lower right corner. R1 seems to read "receiving a halfkhal[of grain; they are to be given?] to'Phan-kol-nyid(or'Phan-kolhimself)." R2 reads "having received, they are to be put on the back of a camel; one fullbreof barley toCung-srin." There may be another line in the missing left half below r2.

Upper part of probably a contract; must be from the same ms. as Text 533, which constitues the lower left corner, but the two frags. cannot be joined together. R1 contains a fragmentary date. Verso is similar in style to recto, but probably a different document.tshal(v1) may be the place nameTshal-[byi]; v2 mentions a Chinese female bondservant (rgya-mois probably not a personal name but a "Chinese woman"). Since "Chinese female bondservant" also appears in Text 533 recto, recto and verso are no doubt related.

Lower left corner; no doubt from the same ms. as Text 532. R3 mentions a Chinese female bondservant. R6 says "the private seal ofRmang-slebsis hereby affixed." On verso are the last two lines of a different document. An officialblonLegs-bzangappears in v2. See Text 532.

note.p: Recto is the middle part of a document. R1 seems to say "[in the] hand ofKa-lde khlu-gse(probably same asKa-lde khlu-gsoin Text 548) inLittle Nob." R2 reads "thirteen watchmen of theRgod-tsang-stod[thousand-district]." Verso is a different document, most likely the last two lines of a contract. V1 mentions "confiscation;" v2 describes "sealing of witness seals."Po-khre(v2) may be the debtor's mame. Faint traces of vermilion seals are visible.'i thog(r1) andla(v1) are crossed out.
Upper part of a letter probably tojo-moKhrom-legs. R1 is the form of address; r2 greetings; r3 mentions "my (i.e., the sender's) old father and mother." The line on verso may be the address.

Probably upper middle part of a document; r1 gives the date; r2 contains the place nameNob-shod. Verso is apparently a different document, probably concerning grain. An officialblonLegs-bzangis mentioned (v2).
Recto is the lower right corner of a document; r3 containsbu-smad"wife and child, family." Verso is apparently a different document, in which only the personal nameRgyal-bzangis clearly legible.
Right portion. Verso is probably the form of address.Rlang zhang-zigmay be the addressee's name.

Middle part of probably a contract; r2 gives the date. Traces of round vermilion seals on r3 and r4. Verso is a different document. "Grain" is mentioned in v3; but writing is indistinct and not clearly legible.

Middle part of probably a letter. Writing is not clearly legible. R3 mentions[b]ka'-gros"council." "Barley" and "sheep" seem to appear in r5. The personal nameg.yu-sgrascan be made out in r7. Verso contains a large spot of vermilion red, which permeates recto.

Contains two different documents, one on each side. Upper edge has been torn off. The beginning few lines of the verso text are missing, but the recto text starts below the missing part and is complete. Evidently recto was written after verso. Both texts are apparently not drafts but original documents. Recto is a contract for selling yaks (seeText 42). Verso is a petition from a courier namedLda-ka wa-lbatortse rjeand other officials inLittle Nob.Lda-ka's hand-letter-measure is written inverted below v13. Four round vermillion seals of witnessees (zhang-lonofficials) appear near the bottom edge. Cf. text 518.

note.p: Recto is the right portion of a Buddhist text. R4–r7 talk of cause and effect, "leaves come out from sprouts; stems from leaves; fruits from stems." The scribe intended to correct the last two syllables in r4 to'bras bu. Verso is scribbling or a draft by a different hand, which reads "Khong-snangloaned sixbreof barley toSe kyo-yo[."

Two contracts are written by different hands, one on each side. Recto is the left half of a contract for loaning grain. Verso is the right half of probably a hire contract. Round vermilion seals appear on both sides.
Lower right portion of a contract for loaning barely. 'Greng-ro khyi-thug and Rtsig-lha rtsa-skyes are mentioned as witnessees in r7. Cf. Text 518.

Nearly complete, but badly torn and smudged. Recto lists the amount of grain delivered to each person, e.g., soldiers, farmers, and soldier-farmers (so-zhing-pain r5). A finger-seal of possiblyRmang-legsis affixed inverted. One or two round vermilion seals appear near the bottom edge. Verso seems to be a contract for the sale of an ass.Nen tsheng-tshengseems to be the seller. Two witnesses are mentioned in v3.

msItem.type: document, loan contract; document concerning fields

note.p: Recto is a loan contract; the object loaned is unknown. SeeText 5. Verso, apparently written by the same hand as recto, is a document concerning fields (zhing-dor). The nameKa-lde khlu-gsoappears on both sides (cf. Text 534).
Lower portion. Though the bottom edge is torn off, r6 seems to be the last line of the document.

msItem.type: Buddhist text, 'Phags-pa tshe dang ye-shes dpag-tu med-pa shes-bya-ba theg-pa chen-po'i mdo (Ārya-Aparimitāyur-nāma-sūtra)

note.p: Texts 550–553 are pieces from the same roll bearingAparimitāyur-nāma-sūtraon recto. Texts 550 and 553 form the beginning first column (Text 553 fills the missing left end in Text 550). The Sanskrit title (r1 in Text 550) seems to be missing due to paper damage. Text 551 and Text 552 each forms the second and the third column. Each column seems to have originally consisted of 18 lines. The reunited text from Texts 550 and 553 is given here. Text 550 verso has only two syllables of a personal name; probably a scribal exercise, written by the same hand as Text 551 verso.

note.p: Recto is a continuation from Text 550. No lines are missing between Text 550, r18 and Text 551, r1. R17 and r18 of Text 551 seem to be missing due to paper damage. Note thatma ha ya nais written asma ha na ya(r11, r14 et passim). The beginning two lines of'Phags-pa rims-nad rab-tu zhi-bar byed-pa'i gzung() is written on verso, apparently scribbling. V3 is also scribbling, apparently written by the same hand as v1 and v2. Site number Ch. 73. XIV. is written in pencil on Text 551 verso and Text 552 verso.
