note.p: This frag. with Chinese text is placed together with the Tibetan mss. (Texts 550–553), thus included in the present catalogue. It may have been written in the margin or on verso of the Tibetan texts. The beginning part ofKong-zi bei-wen-shu{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}is described by Kazuo Enoki as C 116 in Appendix to263. Seefor a more complete frag. of the same text.

Oblong sheet of paper containing two different texts, one on each side; both almost complete, only the bottom edge being torn off. Recto is the upper part of a contract for loaning grain. Writing is indistinct, especially the first three lines hardly legible. Date of the contract is given in r1 as "spring of the horse year"; r4–r5 give standard expressions in loan contracts. Verso is the upper part of a letter fromSam-stangtojo-choRtsang-bzher. Not clearly legible, especially the lower lines.

note.p: Two frags. are pieces of the same ms. and have been joined together. The text thus reconstructed is the lower right corner of a document concerning grain fields. Writing is indistinct and not clearly legible.Zhing-dor(r3) andsa-bon"seeds" (r5) seem to appear.
Joined with M. I. xvi. frag. 1.

M. I. xvi. frag. 2. has been joined to the left bottom corner of M. I. xvi. 19. A dispatch fromZhang-smontoKhong-snang. The verbskuris used (r1) instead ofspring. Verso is a different document, probably a letter. Both the left and right edges seem to have been cut off. Accordingly, verso was written before recto.

note.p: Badly torn and smudged; writing is indistinct and not clearly legible. Only a few syllables, such asbsd[o]ngs nas"having united" (r3) andlan 'dI dgun"the summer of this year" (r5), can be made out.

The number "M. xvi Fr.1" is written on the ms. However, Francke clearly indicates that this ms. is numbered M. I. xvi. 1, and that M. I. xvi. frag. 1 is assigned to another ms. Middle portion of a sale contract.Legs-brtsanis the seller. "Foursrangofdmar" (r3) is the amount of compensation equal to the sale price. The price suggests that the object for sale is livestock, e.g., a cow, ox, or horse.
Upper middle portion. Names of two addressees are partly visible in r1. R2–r4 show greetings. The addressees seem to be calledlha byang-cub phyogsin r2, suggesting that they are priests.
Upper left part (or left half) of a letter addressed tozhang zhangLha-sgra. Personal names, such asYa-bir,Sru-dpal, and'Khu-steng, seem to appear.

note.p: Upper right corner of paper with mythological drawings, such as a snake, a flower with three petals, a flower with four petals, a bird swimming on a pond, a lotus of eight petals, a bird on a stone(?), and an ornament.

Recto is a contract for loaning barley and wheat (cf.Text 24). Verso is an instruction on the collection of repayment. The bottom edge of the paper is torn off. Thus, the lower part of recto (lines below r4) and the upper part of verso (above v1) are missing. A round vermilion seal is faintly visible on the right end of r2, and also to the right of v4. According to Francke, this ms. was rolled round a small stick.

note.p: Middle part of an oblong sheet of paper. Recto is a dispatch addressed toKhrom-skyeswith two lines written at the middle of the sheet. Verso is probably the lower part of a different letter; writing is faint and not clearly legible.chu-srid(v2) is used forchab-srid. The top line is partly cut off. Apparently the paper with the verso text was cut so as to write the recto letter.
Lower right portion. Written in a cursive style, possibly belongs to the post-Tibetan period. "Half and half of white and black [wheat]" is mentioned in r2.

Texts 567 and 568 are pieces of the same ms. According to Francke, they used to bear the same site number M. I. xvi. 0011. R1 and r2 in Text 568, respectively, are likely to be the continuation of r2 and r3 in Text 567. But these two cannot be joined together. Due to paper damage, the text is very fragmentary; but it may be a sort of land register listing the place names and field owners.Te[n?] khang-rngyingandPe-ta-phyemay be the place names. R4 in Text 568 reads "the field of one [. . .] is atPe-ta-phyi." Only relatively clear and decipherable parts are given here.

note.p: Middle portion of probably a letter. Verso is a different text by a different hand. Writing is very faint and hardly legible.

A blank space lies between the two lines near the top edge and the one near the bottom edge. A spot of vermilion red appears in the middle of the space. R2 reads "went to small bird hunting(orwent toBya'u-lIng)."

Frag. of two folios from concertina. Each folio has four lines of text ruled in red ink on both sides; red vertical lines mark the right and left margins of the text. Writing on recto is in an upright sutra style, while verso is in a more cursive style. Recto resembles and possibly belongs with Texts 572, 574–576 recto, which contain part ofGser-'od dam-pa'I rnga-sgra. But no corresponding passages found between Text 571 recto and parallel Dunhuang texts (e.g.,449,). Verso is another Tantric Buddhist text. It speaks of relation and correspondence betweenTrikāya,Trikarma,Trikāla, five causes of mental misery, and five Buddhas, i.e.,Snang-ba mtha-yas(Amitābha),Akṣobhya,Rnam-par snang-mdzad(Vairocana),Amogasiddhi, andRin-can 'byung-ldan(Ratnasaṁbhava). Cf. Text 577 verso.

note.p: Frag. of two folios from concertina. Each folio has four lines of text ruled in red ink on both sides. Similar in style to Text 571. Recto is a passage near the end ofGser-'od dam-pa'i rnga-sgraand corresponds with minor differences to parallel Dunhuang texts (e.g.,449: 27-33,7–14). It continues to Text 574 recto. Texts 575 and 576 are pieces from the same text, to which Texts 571 and 577 may belong. Verso, written in a more cursive style than recto, is another Buddhist text (unidentified) and is probably a continuation from Text 574 verso. V1 mentionsdbu-skra dmar"red hair" andspyan-gsum"three eyes."
Frag. of an oblong sheet of paper with six holes, which seem to have been cut out after having been folded. Placed together with Texts 571, 572, 574–577.

Frag. of two folios from concertina. Recto is a passage near the end ofGser-'od dam-pa'i rnga-sgraand corresponds to parallel Dunhuang texts (e.g.,449: 33–37,14-19). Continuation from Text 572 recto and continues to Text 575 recto. Another Buddhist text on verso is a continuation from Text 575 verso and continues to Text 572 verso.

Continuation from Text 574 recto and continues to Text 576 recto. Another Buddhist text on verso is a continuation from Text 576 verso and continues to Text 574 verso.

note.p: Left half of a folio with small remaining part of another folio. Recto is the ending passage ofGser-'od dam-pa'i rnga-sgraand corresponds to parallel Dunhuang texts (e.g.,449: 42–44,24-26). Continuation from Text 575 recto. R4 may be the beginning of another text. Still another Buddhist text on verso continues to Text 575 verso.

note.p: Right half of a folio, similar in style to Texts 571, 572, 574–576. Recto may be part ofGser-'od dam-pa'i rnga-sgrabut not located in parallel Dunhuang texts. Another Buddhist text on verso mentions BuddhaRnam-par snang-mdzad(v1) and fiveTathāgatas (v4), and resembles Text 571 verso. Texts 571 and 577 probably belong to the same ms., but whether they belong with Texts 572, 574–576 cannot be confirmed.

Nearly complete, except for the torn-off right edge. A dispatch written in letter type 2 formula, addressed toBtsan-sum; the sender's name is not written at the beginning of r1.'am?'chI ma thosin r4 is written below the line.

note.p: Right half of a dispatch, similar in style to Text 578. R4–r6 are written in smaller characters. The lower left corner is torn off, but no characters are missing in r4–r6, suggesting that these lines were written later than r1–r3, but by apparently the same hand.bcol-'a(r3) may be forbcol-ba.
Recto is the right portion of probably a letter; written in an upright style, but indistinct due to paper damage and not clearly legible. Verso is a different letter written in a more cursive style.
Only a few faint characters and hardly legible.
Letter from Dpal-grub. R2 mentions "great power." R3–r4 are too fragmentary to be made out.

] dpal grub kyI mchid gso[l][
] / / mnga' thang chen po 'I [-e][

note.p: Recto is probably a contract for hiring horses. Right and lower edges are torn off; writing indistinct and not clearly legible in parts. R1 gives the date of contract: "In the spring of the ox year, whenblonBtsan-sum-bzher,blonMang-zigs,blonDpal-bzang, and so on [convoked] the assembly atDru-gu;" r3 mentions "a spare(?) horse ofRlang 'brug-legswas hired." Verso is a letter addressed toblonStag-bzangfrom'Brug-legs, probably identical withRlang 'brug-legson recto. Writing is faint and indistinct in parts. Francke suggest that both recto and verso refer to an infectious disease among horses.

Writing is effaced and hardly legible. R1 seems to say "Cattle are inGreat Nob." A phrase "provisions for two months" seems to appear in both r2 and r5. There seems to be an interlinear writing below r1, which may reads[khal] sto. Verso may be the continuation of recto, but very faint and hardly legible, except for a few unconnected syllables, such asmchis pa(v1). The place nameNobseems to appear in v3. Faint traces of two round vermilion seals are visible.
Two distinct contracts appear on each side. Recto is probably a contract for loaning grain. SeeText 54. Verso is a contract for the sale of a cow. SeeText 44. The revised readings are given here.

Upper left corner is torn off. Contract for borrowing grain byMon-tshe skye, a subject of themnganofficial. R2 gives the time of repayment as "[on the . . .] of the intercalated middle winter month of the dog year." R3 reads "[if the borrower should not] repay [by that time], having made [the amount double], threekhalof barley [should be confiscated from] the household of the debtor." R4 states the guarantee for confiscation of the property of the borrower and the compensation by the guarantor, the borrower's younger brother. R6–r7 state the sealing remarks. Two variant spellingskon-ta(r3) andkhong-ta(r7) are used to refer to the debtor.

note.p: Upper left corner of probably a dispatch from Justiciar (zhal-ce-pa)zhang-lonblonStag-bzherto probably the people or officials inNob-chung, regarding some legal issue. R3 mentions a witness seal (dpang-rgya) and witness (che-bzhi).

note.p: R2 mentions "excess or shortage as to the written [document of] payment"; r4 reads "since we were cheated." The text may be a sort of petition regarding a trouble over repayment. R4–r9 are written in much smaller characters. Verso is a different document, probably a loan contract. Writing is indistinct and not clearly legible; both the names of persons concerned and the object loaned are missing due to paper damage.
Probably a letter. Only two legible syllables,zha-sngar /"in the presence [of]" in r2. This may belong to the same ms. as Text 590, but cannot be joined to it.

This frag. may belong to the same ms. as Text 589. Personal names, such asKong-sma,Lha-skyes,Stag-slebs, andShang-gchug, are mentioned.gdod(r1) may readgtod"deliver." No peculiar words or expressions to help identify the content.

Recto is the upper middle part of a document; the top edge seems to remain partly. The personal name,Ro-gzigs, with the title,dbang-bo, is legible. Verso is the lower middle part of a different document concerning grain. "Seed" (v1) and "barley" (v2) are mentioned. There seem to be personal names in r4–r5, but not very clear.

The edges are all torn off. List of the fields of high officials, such asdmag-pon,spyan,dgra-blon,mngan, andrud-pon, and names of farmers who plough the fields to cultivate wheat. The area each farmer is in charge is shown by the measurementdor.

Recto is the lower middle part (the last three lines) of probably a contract, as suggested by the standard expressions found in r2–r3. A round vermilion seal is visible on r3. Verso is frag. of a different document. Since verso text is written on the back of recto's bottom edge, verso was probably written before recto.sman(v1) may be "medicine";gpeg(v2) may be part of a personal name.

Upper middle part of probably a loan contract, judging from the presence of standard expressions in r2–r3.Ldong-pringin theThong-kyabdistrict (r1) seems to be the debtor. The line on verso is probably a continuation from recto. It suggests that the object for loan is barley.
Frag. of probably a contract.Ngan ldong-kong(r2) may be the debtor.
Joined to the right of M. I. xxvii. 18.

M. I. xxvii. 18. is the right half of a letter with four lines and additional writing, r1(add), below r4. It has been joined to the left of M. I. xxvii. 008. The reconstructed text is given here. The lower left half is still missing. The line on verso may be the address.

note.p: Almost complete letter fromblonBtsan-zigstoSmyi-mor,Phag-sme, and so on. Lower right corner is cut in a rectangular shape; many holes and badly smudged; writing indistinct and effaced in many places, the reading remains uncertain. A few round vermilion seals are visible. Verso is a contract for the sale of a horse. It was written before recto, that is, when the right bottom corner was not yet cut off. The bottom edge is cut or torn off. Writing is faint; several lines are not clearly legible. A vermilion seal is partly visible near the right bottom edge.

note.p: Lower or middle part of probably a petition. Paper seems to have been cut out, except for the torn-off upper right corner.skyi-tso(r2), a personal name, seems to be a servant ofspyan"an inspector(?)" (r3).bong-pa(r2) may be either a personal name or the word for "ass." R4 seems to say "having requested to the inspector himself."khre-zhing"millet field" is mentioned in r7.

Left half and upper middle part are torn off. Both the sender's and addressee's names are missing due to paper damage. It concerns the selling of female cattle; the price seems to be 27srangof silver. The sender then asks for the payment. Bothdngul sranganddmar srangappear in r6. Bothmjalandtshongare used to mean "sell."

Badly torn and the left edge is torn off. The text concerns the borrowing of something made of hide byStag gtsug-bzangfromGsas-la-brtsaninPog-rkyang. This contract was given toGsas-la-brtsanto keep (r4).Gsas-la-brtsanalso appears in a wooden slip fromMīrān(M. I. iv. 60. =394). A fragmentary date is visible on verso.
Right half. Writing is very faint. Both the sender's and addressee's names are missing due to paper damage. On verso only a few characters are vaguely visible, possibly the form of address.

Lower left portion of probably a contract for loaning grain. Two round vermilion seals are visible; some other faint traces also exist. Since the upper part is missing, details of the contract remain unknown. Names of the witnesses are listed in r1–r4. A vermilion seal is affixed near the top edge. Verso seems to be the upper right part of a different document, but faint and hardly legible. Only v6 is given here, which seems to say "[in] summer season, one peacock(?) and five hare." "Summer" appears also in v4. The wordbzung"captured" seems to occur a few times.

note.p: A petition to sue filed byPang-tshab rbeg-chungandLdong-prang spra-'u-kongagainst five men employed by them, including three brothers in theRlangfamily. Names of six guarantors are given in r16–r17. R9 states the time for the pleadings. Eight round vermilion seals are barely visible.rIng-lus(r3) is an error forrIng-lugs(r18) "commission."

note.p: Lower middle portion of a folio with a Buddhist text on one side. Not included in Francke. No site number is written on the ms. The attached note bears the site number M. I. xxviii. 002., which has already been given to Text 606 by Stein. Thus, the assignment of the present site number.

Middle portion of probably a roll. Two pages or columns separated by two vertical lines remain partly on recto; two lines on the left page (ra1–ra2) and six lines on the right page (rb1–rb6) are written in an upright sutra style. Text resembles and possibly belongs with Texts 610 and 611 recto, which partly corresponds to theLaṅkāvatāra-sūtra. Verso also consists of two pages, but in a more cursive style.chos-gyI mtshan-nyid(vb5) andsku gsung thugs gyi rang-bzhin(vb10) are mentioned.

msItem.type: Buddhist text, Lang-kar gshegs-pa'i mdo (Laṅkāvatāra-sūtra)?; Tantra?

note.p: Two small frags. of M. I. xxviii. 005. a. have been fit into an area in the middle of M. I. xxviii. 004., making up the missing part of r5–r7; the reconstructed text is given here. It used to form one piece (probably a roll) with Text 611 that bears the same site number; Text 610 recto is the left page and Text 611 recto is the right. Text 611 recto can partly be identified as theLaṅkāvatāra-sūtra, but Text 610 recto does not correspond with the sūtra. Another Buddhist text, probably a Tantra, written in a more cursive style, is on verso, where Text 610 is the right page and Text 611 is the left. Verso mentionsrdo-rje pad-ma'i ting-'dzing(v2),las rnam bzhi(v4),'das-logs(v18).

msItem.type: Buddhist text, Lang-kar gshegs-pa'i mdo (Laṅkāvatāra-sūtra)?; Tantra?

note.p: Text 611 bears the same site number as Text 610. They used to form one piece (probably a roll); Text 611 recto is the right page and Text 610 recto is the left. R4–r8 can be identified as the middle part of theLaṅkāvatāra-sūtra, corresponding to Lhasa ed. 149b2–6; but the remaining part is not the sūtra. Needs further comparison with other relevant texts: e.g.,167and219;and;.sam-gtanis spelled asbsam-brtan(r5). Another Buddhist text, prabably a Tantra, written in a more cursive style, is on verso, where Text 611 is the left page and Text 610 is the right. Text 611 (v3–v4) mentions four continents:'Dzam-ling-dag,Lus-spags-po,Ban-glang-spyod, andDgra-myi-snyan. V7–v9 explains two mystic syllables,omandhum.Rnam-par snang-mdzad(Vairocana) appears in v20.
Complete letter fromShang-rdzongtonang-rje-po blonStag-bzangandblonMdo-bzher. The place nameBye'u-lingappears in r3.

Many holes and badly smudging; writing is indistinct and difficult to decipher. Verso is a letter fromYul-skyestojo-boMdo-rmaandStag-sgra(?) written in six lines. Though the letter is nearly complete, it is difficult to decipher due to paper damage and indistinct writing. The form of address or scribbling appears in two lines near the lower left corner (v7–v8).

note.p: A folio probably from concertina or pothī. Recto and verso are similar in style, both ruled with red lines. Recto describes physical and mental features [of a saint], such as nose, mouth (r1), tongue, throat (r2), mind, legs (r3), and hands (r4); the upper part isVairocana, and the lower part isAvalokiteśvara(r4).

note.p: Recto is the left portion of a text treating ofdhāraṇiand formulas. Another text on verso is faint and not clearly legible.snga-rgyas sna[ng](v1) may meanSang-rgyas snang-ba mtha-yas.Khri rma-byais mentioned in v2. Blank space below v3.
Middle portion of probably a letter. The form of address is missing due to paper damage. R2 may read "I, a bad one,Lha-zhig, is capable."
Writing style is similar to Texts 625 and 626. Probably pieces from the same ms. It also resembles Texts 621–624 recto, but Texts 621–624 have verso texts and are thus probably different.

msItem.type: Buddhist text, dhāraṇi or mantra, Tantric?

note.p: Writing on verso is in the upright sutra style, and recto is in a more cursive style. V2 gives adhāraṇior mantra.TinphaT(v1) shows an early usage of the reversed t for a retroflex stop. No doubt from the same ms. as Texts 622–624.

msItem.type: Buddhist text, dhāraṇi or mantra, Tantric?

note.p: Three frags. (Texts 622–624) bear the same site number M. I. xxxii. 5. h. According to Francke, they were once held together by red cord. Now separated, they are apparently pieces of the same ms. Texts 622 and 623 bear writing on both sides. Verso, consisting of mantras, is written in the upright sutra style, and recto in a more cursive style. For Text 624, only a few unconnected syllables, such assnaandshe, are legible on verso, which apparently belong with the versos of Texts 622 and 623. Recto writing seems faded. The three frags. cannot be joined together. Since their relative position can be inferred, the reconstructed text is given here. They also seem to belong to the same ms. as Text 621.

Middle portion of a letter toKlu-rgyal. It seems to ends at v1. May be joined with Text 627, but not identifiable.

Both left and right edges are torn off. Writing is clear, but not clearly legible in many parts. R1–r5 seem to be a letter fromGsas-seng(?) to[. .]-brtsan. R6–v5 are written in the form of a contract. It seems that the letter and the contract form one text (cf. Texts 382 and 521).

Recto is a letter tojo-coLha-'brul. Written in tiny characters, which are effaced and hardly legible in many places. Verso contains one line (v1) and part of a large square black seal(?) with part of a drawing, probably a bird, and a Tibetan inscription (v2).
Written on thick paper. Though much decayed, three lines are faintly visible, but too effaced to read. There seems to be traces of characters on verso.

Badly worm-eaten, writing is not clearly legible. Personal names, such asblon[Sta]g-bzang,blonMang-[..](r3),Cang byon-zIgs(r4),[..]-legs(r5), and the place nameNob-chungu(r7) can be made out. R5 mentionslo ngam khre [kha]l lnga 'jal du"as payment of five khal of millet in lo-ngam."

Recto is the lower middle portion of most probably a contract. Two personal names are partly visible in r2. R3 gives sealing remarks. Four or five round vermilion seals are visible. Verso is another document written in larger characters than recto. It seems to speak of "wheat and barley as wages" (v2). Thus, it might be a hire contract, but too fragmentary to ascertain.

Both the top and bottom edges are torn off. Recto is written in large distinct characters. Verso is written in regular size characters; apparently a different document from recto, possibly a letter, but too faint to tell.

note.p: Upper middle portion. Names of addressees or senders are partly visible. V2 mentions the date "on the fifteenth of the first autumn month." Text 638 is likely to be part of the same letter, in which the title and part of the namezhang zhang [sngang?]appear in r1. This is probably one of the addressees. The names in Text 637 may then be a continuation from Text 638. The last two lines of another document are partly visible on verso. Only a few unconnected syllables, such asgtad, are legible. Another frag. of the same document is found on verso of Text 638.

Upper middle part of probably a letter. The title and part of a name of probably one of the addressees is visible in r1. No other substantial syllables are legible. On verso the lower four lines of another document are partly visible. Only a few syllables, such asgtang-pa(v3) andyige 'di ni(v4), are legible. Probably belongs to the same ms. as Text 637. See Text 637.

Probably a letter or a petition. Only two lines with four syllables in each remain. The blank space below r2 suggests that r2 is the last line.

note.p: Middle portion. Paper is very thin and badly torn. Only six lines are partly legible. R2 containsbran"bondservant." R7 seems to mention "one[khal]and eightbre[of grain]." Writing style is similar to that of Text 657.

Upper middle part of an official dispatch. R1and r2 give the introductory formula, which reads "From [the assembly of] the great military government (khrom ched-po) convoked by the greatzhang-lonministers atGdag-mkhrar-gong, the seal of the dispatch having been fixed, [this letter is hereby given to] the commissioner (ring-lugs) of the land settlement, the governors of the four towns (mkhar-bzhi), and the [. . of]Nob-chen." R3 and r4 quote a petition by'O-se.

Middle part of a pothī folio. A comparison withPl. CLXXshows that the left edge is missing and writing worn in the present ms. Francke mentions that the page number 53 is given on the left side, but this no longer visible. The recto text given here is reconstructed from the Serindia plate, while the verso is from the present text. V4 mentions "a stupa and offering of butter lamps."Sha-ri-bu(i.e.,Śāriputra) is found in r2. V4 mentions the offering of butter-lamp stupas.

Left portion; badly torn and writing indistinct. A title "governor (dbang-po) ofKhams" is mentioned in r2; r3 may mean "having been enthroned"; r4 seems to say "do whatever; seize the realm." Francke gives the governor's name as "Sum-bzher, the royal minister." Francke probably readblon rgyal sum bzher, namely,blonRgyal-sum-bzher; butsum-bzheris not legible from the present text. Writing style is similar to that of Text 654, but a bit larger. There seem to be four lines on verso, but very faint and hardly legible, except for a few syllables given here.
Left portion. Only a few unconnected syllables are legible; the last word in r2 may besmon-lam. Only one syllable, probably[mchis?], is faintly visible on verso.

note.p: Last three lines of possibly a contract. R1 mentions "onekhalof barley"; r2 gives the date "winter of the horse year." A round vermilion seal is visible to the right of r3.

Upper middle portion containing parts of drawings and two lines of Tibetan written between the drawings. R2 mentions "various diseases." This suggests that the text may be a charm or incantation against illness.

Upper portion. R1 is a greeting. Text 661 is probably from the left part of the same ms.
Only the first line of a document remains on recto; v3 seems to be where the document ended.rabs-chad"break in succession" seems to appear in r1.

Only a few syllables, such asstag,bcol, andpo la, are legible on recto. Verso is illegible. According to Francke, there were two more small frags., one of which contains two syllableslta-bza[ng]; but they are currently missing.

Placed with Khotanese mss. in the plate numbered 205 (they were previously put together in a box with the heading "Central Asia Varia 3/1"). A note with the site number "Kao. III." is put in the plate, but it is not certain whether this applies to this ms. or not. The top and bottom edges partly remain. The left and right edges are torn off. Four lines are partly visible. There is a blank space below the last line.]r sla -brIng-po"the middle [summer] month" (r1) andtha-chungs"the last [month]" (r2) can be read.

Two lines of Tibetan are written interlinearly on the Chinese text. They are apparently a later addition. The Tibetan line on verso is written apparently by the same hand as that on recto.

msItem.type: document, military?; Chinese Buddhist text on verso

note.p: Two frags. have been joined together during the conservation process. The reconstructed text is still fragmentary.'phongs"a kind of military post" (r2, r5) appears in a few other military texts, making a pair with another postdgon(,854). Here it may make a pair withmdung"spear" (r3, r4, r6). R4 has a phrase "to the right [it] is joined to theSkyi-churiver." The text may describe a formation of troops. Six columns of a Chinese Buddhist text on verso is part of the{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}{CH}:vol.16: 720c(28)–721a(4)='Phags-pa sangs-rgyas-kyi sa shes-bya-ba theg-pa chen-po'i mdo().
Upper left part of a blockprint or stamp. This may date a little later than the Old Tibetan period (12–14 c.?).

note.p: Two pieces of the same blockprint known asYedharmā mantraorDharmakāya (śarīra) kārikā(210–211). Probably found from the layers of débris embedded in sand near the stupa base ofKichik-hassārnear the south-east corner of the Turfan basin (1166). Many prints of the same mantra are found in the German Collection (Text 49), the Otani Collection ("Otani": Texts 6027–6070), and the Malov Collection. Cf. Text 673.

note.p: Probably a stamp likeYedharmā mantra(Texts 672 and 673). The original text seems to have been divided into two parts, and only the right part remains. R1 is no doubt the continuation of the last line of the left part. R1 mentionsLha'i dbang-po Brgya-byin"Indra." R2 containsgser-zug chen-po"great pain"; r3,nyams-su myong"experience, feel." The print probably dates a little later than the Old Tibetan period.

note.p: Lower middle portion. Not clearly legible due to paper damage. Red spots appear in a few places.gla"wage" andzhag-du"by the day" in r2 anddpang-rgya"witness seal" in r5 suggest that this is a hire contract similar to Text 357.mkhan(r4, r6) is probablymkhan-po"abbot";ban-de"priest" appears in r7. They are probably either employers or witnesses.

Five Tibetan frags. and one Chinese frag. have been placed in a sack with the requisition number Or.8212/1834. No site numbers are written on the frags. Two paper slips in the sack contain site numbers "LA.VI.ii.0221-227" and "Centre xv.," but neither seem to apply to the Tibetan frags. Three frags. have been joined together (Text 677). One frag. seems to have been written in the Khotan area (= Text 359). Text 676, the smallest piece, is the upper middle portion of probably a letter. An officialblonDgra'-sdogin r1 may be the sender.

Three small frags. have been joined together during the conservation process. The reconstructed ms. is the lower middle part of possibly a letter. May belong to the same text as Text 676. Cf. Text 676 for the requisition number.

Two frags. have been joined together to form the lower middle part of possibly a letter. Writing is badly smudged and not clearly legible. R1 mentions "thanks"thang-ragforgtang-rag. R8 containsbka'-gros"council." Personal names, such asDge-bzher(r6) andLha-dpal(r10), appear.

Recto and verso apparently belong to the same text. Recto may be the continuation from verso. Expressions, such asnas bre bco-lnga"fifteenbreof barley" (r1),stsang bre gsum"threebreof grain" (v3), and amnganofficial (v4), suggest that the text concerns collecting grain tribute.

msItem.type: Buddhist text, 'Phags-pa sa-lu'i ljang-pa zhes-bya-ba theg-pa chen-po'i mdo (Śālistamba-nāma-mahāyāna-sūtra)

note.p: A leaf of theŚālistamba-sūtratexts (Texts 680–693) found in Endere (cf.180, 186–9;). For more details on their provenance, see425–427. The texts were previously published and described by Barnett in549–556. Readings given here include minor revisions, but the reconstructed readings by Barnett based on the Kanjur version have been omitted. Page numbergnyis"two" appears on the left-hand margin of Text 680. The right edge is torn off.

Buddhist Text, 'Phags-pa sa-lu'i ljang-pa zhes-bya-ba theg-pa chen-po'i mdo (Śālistamba-nāma-mahāyāna-sūtra)

note.p: Two frags. have been joined together. The left edge is torn off. Cf. Text 680.

Two Buddhist verses (r1–r7, r8–r17), written byGnam ched-pho(r18). Published inby Barnett with the help of Francke, where the verses are considered to have been taken from theTheg-mchog-mdzod, a 14 c. encyclopaedic work byKlong-chen rab-'byams. However, this ms. is apparently older than the latter from both palaeographic and linguistic aspects. The identified passages, r1–r3 of the first verse andTheg-mchog-mdzod43a2 (wrongly given as 44 in Das: 653), seem to have been taken independently fromNāgārjuna'sMūlamadhyamaka-kārikā(§17, verse 33).

note.p: Recto is a letter fromBzang khyi gu-lod(Khyi gu-lodappears in Text 426), but the addressee is missing. It seemingly talks of sending millet.bad(r3) may readbar. An officialblonLdong-sumis mentioned in r8. There is a triangular cut on the bottom edge. Verso is a different document, probably a letter, written in a more cursive style; possibly belongs to the post-Tibetan period.'Phan-po(?) may be the sender. Personal names, such asLha-sum(v4),Nyo brtan-legs(v5),Ba-leg(v7), andKhra lha-byin(v8), seem to appear. Onekhalof millet is mentioned in v5. Published as Text A in.

Three frags. bearing the same site number (here distinguished by adding a., b., and c.) are pieces of the same ms. with writing on both sides apparently by the same hand. Frag. a. was mistakenly joined to frag. b. (as shown in Plates) and should be reversed so that the the first two lines of a. recto will be joined with b. r2 and r3. This newly reconstructed text is given here. Both recto and verso seem to be parts of a letter. Personal names are not clearly legible;]yu(r1) may be the end of a name; r3 seems to contain[jo]-coLha-dpal. Published as Text C in.

note.p: Two frags. (E. i. 31. b. and E. i. 29.) are pieces of the same ms. and have been loosely joined together. The ms. is reunited by a slip of coarse brownish paper daubed with red paint, especially noticeable on verso. The text, originally consisting of two lines, seems to be a dispatch. R2 says "If [the paper?] does not reach [you] tomorrow because of the heat, go outside to receive it tomorrow[sic]!" This interepretation however remains tentative. Published as Text B in.
